reference: The UCL Student Handbook highlights the importance of student feedback as central to decision-making and improving the educational experience. It emphasizes that students are partners in shaping education at UCL, encouraging them to take part in university-wide surveys and volunteer as academic representatives to work closely with their departments. Specific mechanisms for providing feedback include the student representative scheme, where elected representatives act as the student voice; active dialogue with module leaders via Moodle discussion forums; posting ideas or concerns on the departmental student voice platform; and attending office hours with module leaders, programme directors, or the Departmental Tutor. Additionally, UCL gathers feedback through online student experience surveys such as the National Student Survey, annual programme evaluations, and the New to UCL survey. Regular pulse surveys during modules allow students to reflect on their learning and provide constructive feedback, enabling teaching staff to make improvements before the module ends and for future cohorts.

user_input: How does the Computer Science Head of Department's welcome emphasize the importance of the department's multidisciplinary approach and diversity, and how are Computer Science modules supported through Moodle to facilitate this educational experience?
response:
The Head of Department underscores diversity and a broad, multidisciplinary approach—working across UCL faculties and with industry, health, and government—as central to CS, and Moodle supports this by hosting materials, collaboration tools, assessments, and forums for all taught modules.

- Check each module’s Moodle page regularly for readings, videos, activities, collaboration tools, and assessment details (titles, weightings, deadlines).
- Follow your module’s Moodle forum for tutor updates and Q&A.
- Verify the Assessment section is complete; if not, email the Assessment Team at cs.assessment-team@ucl.ac.uk.
- For self-directed learning on other CS modules, request Moodle access from the Module Leader.

- Caveat: Access to modules you’re not registered on is at the Module Leader’s discretion and may be refused; registered modules are added automatically.

Source: Head of Department's welcome; Moodle (virtual learning environment)
retrieved_contexts:
One word captures the uniqueness of our department: diversity. We adopt a broad definition of what it means to be a computer scientist. While we embrace fundamental theory, we also have a strong emphasis on applications and translation of theory into practical tools that impact the real world. We are highly multidisciplinary, working closely with every other UCL faculty linking to medicine and health, arts and humanities, politics and law, education, maths and life sciences. We collaborate with partners in industry, health services, and government to translate computational advances to impact. We are committed to removing barriers to achieving excellence and fostering inclusive and diverse cohorts of students and staff. The creativity and breadth of ideas this provides is key to exploiting core computer science skills effectively. These values and activities pervade the teaching we deliver to you.  
So I encourage you to embrace the opportunities of being part of this amazing place. Help shape the department and the discipline as they evolve into the future. And let them shape you as a computer scientist and a human being.  
I am excited to meet you and look forward to working with you all over the coming year.  
Prof. Daniel Alexander Head of Department  
Teaching and Learning Team welcome  
A warm welcome to our new students and welcome back to our returning students.

Subject Support Guides - Computer Science | UCL Library Services  
Moodle (virtual learning environment)  
Information on how to access Moodle and support contacts.  
Moodle is UCL's online learning space. It includes a wide range of tools which can be used to support learning and teaching. Moodle is used to supplement taught modules, in some cases just by providing essential information and materials, but it can also be integrated more fully, becoming an essential component of a module. Some modules may use Moodle to provide access to readings, videos, activities, collaboration tools and assessments.  
All taught modules at Computer Science have a Moodle page that supports their delivery. Depending on the approach taken by the Module Leader, the Moodle page may be used more or less intensively, particularly where alternative teaching environments are used in addition. Students should pay close attending to their module's Moodle forum, as this is where tutors will usually post updates about classes and answer questions.  
Assessment information on Moodle  
Each module's Moodle page must include an assessment section that sets out the module's summative assessment information, including the titles and weightings of the assessments and any submission deadlines. If this information is not present, then please contact the Assessment Team (cs.assessment-team@ucl.ac.uk).  
Access to Moodle pages  
Students will be automatically granted access to the Moodle pages of modules for which they are registered. They may request access to the pages of Computer Science modules for which they are not registered, for self-directed learning (or 'auditing'), however this is at the discretion of the Module Leader and may be refused.  
Moodle Resource Centre | UCL Wiki  
Portico

UCL is a community of great minds. You are a valuable member of that community. I hope you will take every opportunity to shape your time with us, so that your experience is the best possible.  
Dr Michael Spence  
UCL President and Provost  
Head of Department's welcome  
Welcome to UCL's Department of Computer Science.  
Our discipline is set to produce the biggest technological advances of this century. It will have profound influence on life on Earth. It is all of you that will lead these advances. Our aim is to equip you to achieve that with skill, rigour, integrity, and a clear and complete understanding of how your work influences the world.  
It starts with the basics: understanding new concepts; solving problems; debugging code; writing reports. These are the skills that enable the sublime: revolutions in AI, healthcare, finance, media, the way we learn, work, and govern the country.

Prof. Daniel Alexander Head of Department  
Teaching and Learning Team welcome  
A warm welcome to our new students and welcome back to our returning students.  
We are very excited to have you with us this year and we're looking forward to supporting you through your time with us. We hope this handbook will serve as a useful companion on your academic journey: it sets out key contacts in the department, and the wide array of academic, pastoral, and welfare support options available to you as a UCL student. It also includes the broad framework of rules and regulations that govern our degrees.  
In addition to the handbook, your programme has a dedicated member of the Teaching and Learning Team who can advise you on a whole host of issues and can connect you with the best source of support. You will have met your Teaching and Learning Administrator during induction week, and you can find their details on the Teaching and Learning contact page.  
You have access to the Computer Science Student Intranet, which is a live space where you'll be able to connect with news, events, and current goings on around the department and faculty. The intranet will grow and evolve further as we better understand your needs, and we will work with you through your Student Representatives to get your input and make this a useful resource for all our students.  
A key contact for you during your time studying at UCL is your Student Representative. They are a fellow student on your degree programme and are there to present the views of your cohort. Through discussion and collaboration with staff in the department they aim to make your experience the best it can be. Find out more about them via the student intranet.
reference: In the Head of Department's welcome, Prof. Daniel Alexander highlights the uniqueness of the Computer Science department by emphasizing its broad definition of what it means to be a computer scientist, embracing both fundamental theory and strong applications that impact the real world. He stresses the department's highly multidisciplinary nature, working closely with other UCL faculties such as medicine, health, arts and humanities, politics and law, education, maths, and life sciences. This collaboration with industry, health services, and government partners aims to translate computational advances into real-world impact. The department is also committed to fostering inclusive and diverse cohorts of students and staff, recognizing that the creativity and breadth of ideas this diversity provides is key to effectively exploiting core computer science skills. This multidisciplinary and diverse approach pervades the teaching delivered to students. Complementing this educational philosophy, all taught Computer Science modules have dedicated Moodle pages that support their delivery. Moodle serves as UCL's online learning environment, providing access to essential information, readings, videos, activities, collaboration tools, and assessments. The use of Moodle varies by module but is integral to supplementing taught content and facilitating communication between tutors and students, including posting updates and answering questions. Each module's Moodle page includes detailed assessment information, ensuring students are well-informed about their coursework. This digital support system aligns with the department's commitment to providing a comprehensive and accessible learning experience that reflects its multidisciplinary and diverse values.

user_input: How do the UCL Student Attendance Policy and the UCL Student Disciplinary Procedures collectively define the expectations for student engagement and conduct, and what are the consequences of non-compliance with these policies?
response:
They require you to meet minimum attendance and record engagement, uphold the Student Code of Conduct, and note that non‑compliance can lead to UKVI reporting (for Student Visa students) and action under Student Disciplinary Procedures.

- Read the UCL Student Attendance Policy, the CS Student Engagement Policy 2024–25, and your departmental Engagement and Attendance guidance.
- Record attendance at scheduled events (scan your UCL ID in equipped rooms; access online sessions with your UCL credentials) and follow any programme/module requirements.
- If you face attendance issues or an absence, contact your programme administration team promptly and follow the department’s absence process; for missed/late assessments due to extenuating circumstances, submit a Short-term Illness and Extenuating Circumstances application.
- Familiarise yourself with the Student Code of Conduct, exam conduct, and academic integrity guidance; clarify assessment conduct requirements with examiners.

Warnings: Student Visa students’ non‑engagement is monitored via RegisterUCL and reported to UKVI; inappropriate behaviour may trigger Student Disciplinary Procedures; repeated academic misconduct can lead to exclusion.

Source: UCL Student Attendance Policy; Chapter 3, Section 3: Attendance and Absence; UCL Code of Conduct; UCL Disciplinary Code and Procedure in Respect of Students (UCL Academic Manual)
retrieved_contexts:
The Engagement policy is available via the student intranet, and students should ensure they understand the policy, and the consequences of non-adherence: CS Student Engagement Policy for 2024-25.  
Each Faculty sets minimum attendance requirements for its programmes, which are set out in the UCL Student Attendance Policy. Students should familiarise themselves with the policy and any specific attendance requirements that apply to their programme or modules. Students must ensure they engage with any requirements in place for recording their attendance at scheduled events (e.g., by using their UCL Student ID to scan in into events that takes place in rooms equipped with card-readers and accessing online teaching sessions using their UCL credentials.)  
Students should also familiarise themselves with the departmental guidance on Engagement and Attendance, so they are aware of the support available to them, and the process to follow if they are absent.  
Students encountering issues with attendance are advised to contact the respective programme administration team as soon as possible.  
Chapter 3, Section 3: Attendance and Absence | UCL Academic Manual  
UCL Student Attendance Policy | UCL Academic Manual  
Attendance at UCL | UCL Students  
Student Visa students: Absence from teaching and learning activities  
In line with UCL's obligations under UK immigration laws, UCL is required to report to UK Visas and Immigration (UKVI) when a student has not been engaging with their studies. RegisterUCL is used by departments and the central Student Immigration Compliance team to report on student attendance. This is not only to meet the UKVI requirements, but also to identify any problems as early as possible to ensure action is taken to advise or assist the student.

Our expectations of students  
Information on UCL's expectations of students, including student conduct and engagement with their programme of study.  
UCL Code of Conduct  
UCL enjoys a reputation as a world-class university. It was founded on the basis of equal opportunity, being the first English university to admit students irrespective of their faith and cultural background and the first to admit women. UCL expects its members to refrain from interfering with the proper functioning or activities of UCL, or of those who work or study at UCL. Students should ensure they read and familiarise themselves with UCL's Student Code of Conduct and other related policies and should be aware that any inappropriate behaviour may lead to actions under UCL's Student Disciplinary Procedures.  
UCL Code of Conduct for Students | UCL Academic Manual  
UCL Disciplinary Code and Procedure in Respect of Students | UCL Academic Manual  
UCL Prevention of Bullying, Harassment and Sexual Misconduct Policy | UCL Academic Manual  
UCL Code of Practice on Freedom of Speech | UCL Student and Registry Services  
Religion and Belief Equality Policy for Students | UCL Students

In particular, students should familiarise themselves with: - the academic integrity guidelines, as set out on the Current Students - Academic Integrity webpage. - the UCL Moodle course 'Introduction to Academic Integrity'. - examination conduct requirements, as set out in the UCL Examination Guide for Candidates, which is published annually on the Examinations and Awards website. - Guidance provided by module examiners in relation to the assessments they set.  
In addition, students are strongly encouraged to clarify with their assessment-setters any requirements that relate to their academic conduct in those assessments, including for example: - referencing conventions; - opportunities for, or restrictions on, collaboration with others; - attribution of contributions in group work; and - any requirements to use plagiarism tools prior to submission.  
The vast majority of students at UCL will maintain their academic integrity throughout their studies, but it is important to be aware that UCL may consider breaches to students' academic integrity as an instance of academic misconduct. When Academic Misconduct occurs, there can potentially be penalties imposed, and it is important to note that repeated breaches will be taken very seriously and could result in exclusion from UCL, as per the Student Academic Misconduct Procedure Adjudication Framework.  
For students who are unsure of what may be considered as academic misconduct, the procedures in Chapter 6 of the Academic Manual define all such behaviour and how this is taken forwards. UCL also has online tools available to help students identify what behaviours may be considered as academic misconduct (for example, the Turnitin service can be used to help students ensure their written work is properly attributed.)

Immigration and visas | UCL Students  
Student visa responsibilities | UCL Students  
Chapter 3, Section 3: Attendance and Absence | UCL Academic Manual  
All students: absence from assessment  
If a student experiences extenuating circumstances that prevents them from attending a scheduled assessment activity or submitting work by the relevant deadline, then they should submit an application under the Short-term Illness and Extenuating Circumstances procedure.  
[Extenuating Circumstances and Reasonable Adjustments | CS Student Handbook](
reference: The UCL Student Attendance Policy requires students to attend all scheduled learning events on their timetable, including lectures, tutorials, and personal tutorials, as attendance is essential for academic success. Students must engage with attendance recording methods, such as scanning their UCL Student ID at card-reader-equipped rooms or accessing online sessions with their credentials. Faculties set minimum attendance requirements detailed in the policy, and students should familiarize themselves with both the central policy and any specific departmental guidance. Failure to meet attendance requirements may lead to penalties, and students experiencing attendance issues are advised to contact their programme administration promptly. Concurrently, the UCL Student Disciplinary Procedures, as outlined in the UCL Code of Conduct, expect students to maintain appropriate conduct by refraining from interfering with the university's functioning or the activities of others. Inappropriate behaviour, including breaches of conduct, may result in disciplinary actions under these procedures. Together, these policies emphasize that students must actively engage with their studies and uphold standards of behaviour, with non-compliance potentially leading to academic penalties or disciplinary measures.

The Integrated Engineering Programme (IEP) is a framework of modules and activities taken by students on participating undergraduate programmes across the Faculty of Engineering Sciences. The Teaching Support Coordinator is responsible for managing teaching support across all programmes and for the effective running of teaching support work undertaken by research staff and PhD students. user_input: How does the Computer Science Head of Department's welcome emphasize the importance of skill development and diversity in the department, and how are the assessment periods for Computer Science modules structured to accommodate students' workloads?
response:
The Head’s welcome stresses diversity and multidisciplinary collaboration and the importance of mastering core skills (concepts, problem-solving, debugging, report writing) for real-world impact; the excerpts do not explain how assessment periods are structured to accommodate workloads.

- For assessment-timing details, check each module’s Moodle and the UCL Examination Guide for Candidates (see “Examinations”).
- Ask your Module Leader or Programme Director about assessment schedules and workload planning for their module(s).
- If feedback on an assessment is delayed without prior Moodle notice, inform the Departmental Tutor or your Course Representative.
- Note: provisional marks are usually released for coursework (not exams), exam scripts are not returned, and exam feedback is cohort-level.

Source: Head of Department's welcome; Section 5: Assessment Feedback; Examinations; Computer Science provisional marks policy; Computer Science exam script policy
retrieved_contexts:
One word captures the uniqueness of our department: diversity. We adopt a broad definition of what it means to be a computer scientist. While we embrace fundamental theory, we also have a strong emphasis on applications and translation of theory into practical tools that impact the real world. We are highly multidisciplinary, working closely with every other UCL faculty linking to medicine and health, arts and humanities, politics and law, education, maths and life sciences. We collaborate with partners in industry, health services, and government to translate computational advances to impact. We are committed to removing barriers to achieving excellence and fostering inclusive and diverse cohorts of students and staff. The creativity and breadth of ideas this provides is key to exploiting core computer science skills effectively. These values and activities pervade the teaching we deliver to you.  
So I encourage you to embrace the opportunities of being part of this amazing place. Help shape the department and the discipline as they evolve into the future. And let them shape you as a computer scientist and a human being.  
I am excited to meet you and look forward to working with you all over the coming year.  
Prof. Daniel Alexander Head of Department  
Teaching and Learning Team welcome  
A warm welcome to our new students and welcome back to our returning students.

UCL is a community of great minds. You are a valuable member of that community. I hope you will take every opportunity to shape your time with us, so that your experience is the best possible.  
Dr Michael Spence  
UCL President and Provost  
Head of Department's welcome  
Welcome to UCL's Department of Computer Science.  
Our discipline is set to produce the biggest technological advances of this century. It will have profound influence on life on Earth. It is all of you that will lead these advances. Our aim is to equip you to achieve that with skill, rigour, integrity, and a clear and complete understanding of how your work influences the world.  
It starts with the basics: understanding new concepts; solving problems; debugging code; writing reports. These are the skills that enable the sublime: revolutions in AI, healthcare, finance, media, the way we learn, work, and govern the country.

The department will proactively monitor the return of feedback for Computer Science modules, and will take appropriate action where delays occur. Students should expect that any delay will be notified in advance via the module's Moodle forum. If this does not occur, students should notify the Departmental Tutor either directly or via their Course Representative.  
Computer Science exam script policy  
UCL is generally unable to return written examination scripts and will not do so as a means of providing feedback. Feedback on examinations should usually take the form of cohort-level feedback, which summarises general issues and areas for improvement based on the performance of the cohort. Individualised or highly detailed feedback is neither appropriate or possible for examinations.  
Computer Science provisional marks policy  
UCL permits departments to release provisional marks for assessments prior to their confirmation by the Board of Examiners. For coursework, provisional marks will usually be released alongside feedback on the assessment; sometimes feedback will be released first, and provisional marks will follow. For examinations, provisional marks will not be released, since the exams take place very close to the point confirmed results are published. In all cases, final marks will be released via Student Registry Services, following their confirmation by the Board of Examiners.  
Section 5: Assessment Feedback | UCL Academic Manual  
Examinations  
Information on written examinations and a link to the UCL Examination Guide for Candidates on the Examinations and Awards website.  
An examination is a short duration test-like assessment that is taken under specific conditions, usually at a fixed time, and which requires adherence to a strict code of practice.

Each module/ module delivery has a fixed upper limit on the number of places available (known as the 'module cap'), based on the department's teaching capacity and other resource constraints.  
Students are guaranteed a place on any modules that are compulsory on their programme/ year of study. However, places cannot be guaranteed on modules that are optional and elective, as availability will depend on how many places are left once any compulsory places have been assigned (i.e. a module that is optional on their programme may be compulsory on another.) Therefore, places will usually be allocated in the following order of priority: - Students for whom the module is compulsory (guaranteed a place.) - Students for whom the module is optional. - Students for whom the module is elective.  
Within those tiers, places will by default be allocated first to Computer Science students and then to non-Computer Science students on a first-come-first-serve basis within each group. If a student selects an optional or elective module that has no capacity remaining, is not formally available to them, or for which they do not satisfy any prerequisites, then their selection will be rejected, and they will be asked to select an alternative module.  
All module selections are ultimately subject to approval by the Module Leader and Programme Director.  
Overlapping content & re-registering on the same module  
Students must not select as optional or elective any module they have already taken, either in their current programme or during any prior studies. For example, if a module is available as an option in multiple terms or years of a programme, it can only be taken and passed once.
reference: In the Computer Science Head of Department's welcome, Prof. Daniel Alexander highlights the importance of developing fundamental skills such as understanding new concepts, solving problems, debugging code, and writing reports, which are essential for achieving technological advances in areas like AI, healthcare, and finance. He also emphasizes the department's unique focus on diversity, adopting a broad definition of what it means to be a computer scientist, combining fundamental theory with practical applications, and fostering inclusive and diverse cohorts. Regarding assessments, the department carefully manages assessment dates to consider students' workloads. Assessments for Computer Science modules typically include coursework, tests, presentations, and examinations. Coursework submissions usually occur during the term in which the module is delivered plus two to three weeks. Examinations take place from 29 April to 30 May 2025, with additional late summer assessment periods and a January resit period for postgraduate taught programmes. Assessment deadlines may be set during Reading Weeks but not during closure periods, weekends, or UK bank holidays, ensuring a balanced workload for students.

user_input: How does UCL's Information Security Policy guide students in protecting their data, and what informal resolution options are recommended before submitting a formal complaint regarding data protection issues?
response:
Encrypt sensitive data, securely back up encryption keys, and use UCL-backed storage (file stores/UCL Dropbox); before a formal complaint, try informal resolution via your programme contacts or the Students’ Union Advice Service.

- Save work on UCL file stores; request additional storage from the Technical Support Group if needed.
- Encrypt any sensitive data and securely back up the encryption key.
- If using your own device, keep independent backups; use UCL Dropbox to securely exchange large files.
- For concerns, speak informally to your Personal Tutor, Programme Leader, Departmental/Faculty Tutor, Course Rep, or Research Student Rep.
- Get confidential advice via the Students’ Union Advice Service (online contact form); you can also email the University Data Protection Officer at data-protection@ucl.ac.uk for data protection queries.

Note: Data loss is not usually acceptable grounds for Extenuating Circumstances.

Source: Storing and securing data; Information Security | UCL; Data protection and intellectual property; Student complaints (Informal resolution)
retrieved_contexts:
If students need to store or exchange sensitive data, then this should be appropriately encrypted. Where data is encrypted, the encryption key should be securely backed up to avoid data loss.  
Information Security | UCL  
File storage & sharing | UCL Information Services Division  
Encryption | UCL Information Security

Data protection and intellectual property  
Information on how UCL uses student information, for what purposes, and the steps taken to safeguard this information; where to find information security, intellectual property and email policies; Information on how to enquire or make a related complaint. Where to find information security, intellectual property, and email policies.  
Data protection (how UCL uses student information)  
UCL uses student information for a range of purposes, including the provision of teaching and learning, managing accommodation and ensuring health and safety. Further information about how UCL uses student information can be found in the UCL General Student Privacy Notice.  
Students may send queries on data protection matters to the University Data Protection Officer (data-protection@ucl.ac.uk.)  
Information Security Policy | UCL  
Email Usage Policy | UCL  
Data Protection Policy | UCL  
Understand your intellectual property (IP) rights | UCL Innovation & Enterprise  
Report a Breach of Personal Data | UCL  
Storing and securing data  
Students are strongly encouraged to save their work on UCL's file stores, which are backed-up regularly. Storage space is finite, however students can request additional storage space from the Technical Support Group, for example where they are required to produce assets with significant file size.  
If students save work to their own devices, they should ensure their files are appropriately backed up to protect against data loss (which is not usually acceptable grounds for Extenuating Circumstances.) The UCL Dropbox service may be used to securely exchange files that may be too large for email or other services.

The service is free, independent, impartial and confidential. No information shared with the service is shared with the students department or any other university staff unless the student requests it or gives their permission. Students can complete the online contact form for advice and support.  
Student complaints  
Information on informal and formal student complaints.  
UCL aims to ensure that every student is satisfied with their experience of UCL. However, we recognise that from time-to-time problems do arise and students may wish to express concern or dissatisfaction with aspects of UCL or the quality of services provided.  
Before raising a complaint, Computer Science encourages students to ensure they have fully explored all options and avenues for discussion available to them.  
Whilst students do not need to strictly follow the route of escalation indicated below, many issues, and the need to escalate, can be avoided by speaking to the right people in the first instance.  
Informal resolution  
Many complaints can be resolved at an informal or local level without needing to submit a formal complaint. Students can speak to their Personal Tutor, Programme Leader, Departmental or Faculty Tutor, Course Representative, or Research Student Representative if they have any concerns about their programme. They can also speak to the Students' Union's Advice Service. UCL strongly encourages this kind of resolution and does expect students to have attempted some form of informal resolution before making a formal complaint.

Equity, Diversity & Inclusion | UCL Computer Science  
UCL’s approach to preventing and responding to harmful behaviours  
Information about UCL’s approach to preventing and responding to harmful behaviours.  
Bullying, harassment, sexual misconduct and/or domestic abuse  
Every student and member of staff has a right to work and study without experiencing harm. Bullying, harassment, sexual misconduct and/or domestic abuse of one member of our community by another or others is never ok. UCL is working to eradicate these issues and seeks to promotes an environment in which they are known to be unacceptable and where individuals have the confidence to raise concerns in the knowledge that they will be dealt with appropriately and fairly.  
To help with this, UCL has Report and Support, an on-line reporting tool where students can report any issues anonymously or with contact details request to speak to an advisor in order to make an informed decision about their options.  
Examples of unacceptable behaviour include, but are not limited to: - Intimidating, hostile, degrading, humiliating or offensive behaviour which has the purpose or effect of violating a person’s dignity or creating an intimidating environment. - Unwanted conduct related to a protected characteristic that has the purpose or effect of violating a person’s dignity. The unwanted conduct can be physical, verbal, or non-verbal. - Unacceptable behaviour of a sexual nature such as sexual harassment, invitations, comments, coercion and promised advancement in exchange for sexual access.
reference: UCL's Information Security Policy advises students to safeguard their data by using UCL's file stores, which are regularly backed up, and by ensuring that any sensitive data stored or exchanged is appropriately encrypted with secure backup of encryption keys. Students are encouraged to save their work on UCL's file stores or use the UCL Dropbox service for securely exchanging large files. If students save work on their own devices, they should back up files properly to avoid data loss. For any data protection queries, students can contact the University Data Protection Officer at data-protection@ucl.ac.uk. Regarding complaints, UCL recommends that students attempt informal resolution before submitting a formal complaint. This includes speaking to their Personal Tutor, Programme Leader, Departmental or Faculty Tutor, Course Representative, Research Student Representative, or the Students' Union's Advice Service. UCL strongly encourages resolving issues locally and expects students to have tried informal resolution to address concerns about their programme or data protection matters before escalating to a formal complaint.

user_input: What are the key deadlines and procedures for programme transfers between the MEng and BSc Computer Science programmes, and where can students find the relevant programme key contacts for assistance?
response:
Apply via Portico with Year 2 Co‑ordinator permission before the end of Year 2; the deadline for both BSc↔MEng transfers is Week 49 (30 July 2025, 5pm), and programme key contacts are listed in Section 2 - Key staff relating to programmes and modules.
- Seek academic advice from your Personal Tutor or Programme Director and obtain permission from the Year 2 Co‑ordinator.
- Submit your programme transfer request in Portico before the end of Year 2 and no later than Week 49 (30 July 2025, 5pm).
- If you are on a Tier 4 Visa, get advice from UCL Visa Compliance before making the transfer request (see Academic Manual Chapter 3, Section 5.2 Programme Transfers).
- For procedural queries contact the Programme Administrator (UG: cs.undergraduate-students@ucl.ac.uk).
- Find programme key contacts in Section 2 - Key staff relating to programmes and modules.

Source: Changes to registration status; Programme details and summaries (Programme key contacts)

Key contacts for changes to programme registration status  
If a student wishes to change their module selections, transfer to a different programme of study within UCL, interrupt their studies, or withdraw from their programme entirely, they should contact their Personal Tutor or Programme Director for advice and guidance in the first instance. The Programme Administrator (Undergraduate students should contact cs.undergraduate-students@ucl.ac.uk and Postgraduate Taught students should contact cs.pgt-students@ucl.ac.uk) is able to provide procedural advice, but cannot advise on the academic merits of a decision to change status.

Programme details and summaries  
Details of programmes' key contacts, structures, durations, modules, and qualification conferred.  
Programme key contacts  
Programme key contacts are summarised in [Section 2 - Key staff relating to programmes and modules](  
Programme summaries (structure, duration, credits, qualifications, etc.)  
The programme summary is a multi-purpose document which is intended as the single source of information pertaining to a UCL programme. The programme summary specifies a programme's learning outcomes, structure, details of any Integrated Study Abroad Year or Additional Placement Year variants, details of any non-condonable modules or components, Progression and Award rules, the Final Award and any Interim or Alternative Awards available, and the corresponding Classification Schemes. The programme summaries are live documents that may be updated through the course of the academic year.  
Overview of programme rules  
The information below summarises the progression and award requirements that are in place on the department's programmes. Students who are in any doubt whether the rules apply to them should proactively contact their Programme Administrator.  
BSc Computer Science; MEng Computer Science; MEng Mathematical Computation  
Students who first entered the programme in 2019/20 or later will be under the standard UCL Honours Degree Progression and Award Requirements.  
Students who first entered the programme in 2018/19 or earlier will be under additional non-standard rules due to the programme's legacy accreditation, summarised as follows:
reference: Applications to transfer from the MEng Computer Science to BSc Computer Science must be made via Portico only after permission has been granted by the Year 2 Co-ordinator, and the deadline for such transfers is Week 49, 30 July 2025, at 5pm. Similarly, applications to transfer from the BSc Computer Science to MEng Computer Science also require permission from the Year 2 Co-ordinator and must be submitted via Portico by the same deadline. Students on Tier 4 visas must seek advice from UCL Visa Compliance before making a transfer request. For assistance and further information, students can refer to the programme key contacts summarized in Section 2 - Key staff relating to programmes and modules, as detailed in the programme summaries, which serve as the single source of information for UCL programmes.

user_input: How do Student Quality Reviewers contribute to the Student Partnership Committee's efforts to improve the student experience at UCL, and what role does student feedback play in this process?
response:
Student Quality Reviewers provide in‑depth, student‑led evidence that SPCs can use to develop and prioritise improvements, and wider student feedback guides these decisions across UCL.

- Get involved as a Student Quality Reviewer to conduct detailed reviews (e.g., Internal Quality Review panels, programme/assessment design roles, ChangeMakers Teaching Dialogue, Student Curriculum Partner).
- Share your insights with your Academic Representatives/Lead Department Representative so they can be raised at the Student Partnership Committee (meets at least three times a year).
- Continuously feed input via MEQs at the end of term, Moodle discussion forums, your departmental student voice platform, and by attending staff office hours.
- Stand in (or vote in) Academic Rep elections in early October; reps receive Students’ Union training to represent your cohort in SPCs.

Caveats: Office hours may not run every week—email staff if none are available; SPCs may be split UG/PG; SQR roles are paid (£300 for ~25 hours).

Source: Student Quality Reviewers; Departmental Student Partnership Committee; Student feedback
retrieved_contexts:
Student Quality Reviewers  
Information on what Student Quality Reviewers are and how students can get involved.  
Student Quality Reviewers, where UCL students take an in-depth look at different areas of education and provide detailed feedback and analysis from a student perspective.  
Through the Student Quality Reviewer scheme, students can: - Act as a member of an Internal Quality Review panel; - Take on a role to review new programmes or support enhancements to assessments through the Programme or Assessment Design Student Partner roles; - Work with staff to reflect on their teaching through the ChangeMakers Teaching Dialogue scheme; - Provide a student view on how teaching can include more diverse perspectives as a Student Curriculum Partner; - Students are paid a stipend of £300 for around 25 hours work.

Chapter 9, Section 7: Student Representation on UCL Academic Standing Committees and Sub-Committees | UCL Academic Manual  
Student voice - other ways to feed back  
Other ways (specific to the department/ programme) that students can give feedback, including local processes and key contacts.  
Staff office hours  
Each Programme Director and Module Leader will hold a regular office hour during term time (for modules this will be during the term in which the module is delivered.) These sessions are intended as informal drop-ins where students can raise any issues of concerns, ideas for improvement, or problems they may be experiencing. Students are welcome to attend these sessions without notification or appointment; most sessions operate a lobby-based queue system.  
Office hours will either be listed in the timetable or advertised to students by the responsible staff. The aim is for these sessions to run regularly, but they cannot be guaranteed to run every week. Students should feel free to contact the relevant staff by email where an office hour is not available.  
[Office Hours & Drop-in Sessions | CS Student Handbook](  
Surveys and questionnaires  
Students will be invited to provide feedback on their individual modules via Module Evaluative Questionnaires (MEQs) at the end of each term. These questionnaires ask about a students' learning experience, the resources and materials they have been provided with, the teaching they have received, and their views on what could be improved. More information on student feedback surveys is given in [Section 18 Student feedback and You Shape UCL | CS Student Handbook](  
Student forum

Elections  
Academic Representatives are appointed during early October. If a student takes up a representative role, the Students' Union will work closely with them to provide training, support, and advice, and they'll be able to change the experience of everyone on their course or in their department for the better. Even if a student doesn't want to take up a role, they should keep an eye out for a chance to vote for which students they feel will do the best job.  
[CS Student Partnership Committees & Academic Representatives | CS Student Intranet](  
Academic Representatives | Students' Union UCL  
Find your representative | Students' Union UCL  
Chapter 9, Section 6: Student Academic Representation | UCL Academic Manual  
Departmental Student Partnership Committee  
Information on the role of the Departmental Student Partnership Committee.  
Every department at UCL has a Student Partnership Committee (SPC) that meets at least three times a year. Student Partnership Committees are meetings where Academic Reps and staff work together to develop solutions to students' concerns, and prioritise areas for improvement. SPCs are co-chaired by your Lead Department Representative. Some departments have a single SPC, while others split this into different levels of study. Most commonly, departments operate both an undergraduate and postgraduate SPC.  
[CS Student Partnership Committees & Academic Representatives | CS Student Intranet](  
Chapter 9, Section 6.4: Staff Student Consultative Committees | UCL Academic Manual  
Chapter 9, Section 7: Student Representation on UCL Academic Standing Committees and Sub-Committees | UCL Academic Manual  
Student voice - other ways to feed back

Student feedback  
The role of student feedback  
The importance of feedback and how UCL uses the results.  
Our goal is to put students' feedback, insights and contributions at the heart of decision-making. We value students' feedback and work with students as partners in the process of shaping education at UCL. In recent years, as a direct result of student feedback, we have opened the Library over the Christmas closure period and increased study space - including 1000 in the 24-hour new Student Centre, we've focussed more on environmental sustainability and given clearer information about exams and assessments.  
The framework of committees, processes, and activities through which students can provide feedback includes: - The student representative scheme, where the student body elects representatives across its programmes to act as the student voice (see Section 17 Student representation and voice | CS Student Handbook.  
Other opportunities for students to feed back on their experience include active dialogue with their module leaders via Moodle discussion forums, posting ideas or issues of concerns to their departmental student voice platform, or attending office hours with module leaders, programme directors, or with the Departmental Tutor.  
You Shape UCL | UCL  
Survey News and Results | UCL  
Student surveys  
Student surveys and how UCL uses the results, including information about the NSS, PTES and New to UCL survey.
reference: Student Quality Reviewers at UCL play a significant role by providing detailed feedback and analysis from a student perspective on various areas of education. They participate as members of Internal Quality Review panels, review new programmes, support enhancements to assessments, and collaborate with staff to reflect on teaching quality and curriculum diversity. Their contributions align with the Student Partnership Committees (SPCs), which are co-chaired by Lead Department Representatives and meet at least three times a year to develop solutions to student concerns and prioritize improvements. Student feedback, gathered through multiple channels including surveys, module dialogues, and the student representative scheme, is central to this process. It ensures that students' insights and contributions are at the heart of decision-making, enabling SPCs and Quality Reviewers to work together effectively to enhance the student experience at UCL.

user_input: How does the role of the Student Representative at UCL support student and staff entrepreneurs in enhancing the student experience within the Department of Computer Science?
response:
Student Representatives enhance the student experience by gathering and presenting student feedback, co-developing solutions with staff in SPC/SSCCs, and communicating improvements (no entrepreneurship-specific support is described). 
- In early October, stand for election as an Academic Representative or vote; the Students’ Union provides rep training, support, and advice. 
- Contact your Academic Representative (or find them via the Students’ Union) to share ideas, issues, and proposals. 
- Feed proposals through the Student Partnership Committee (co-chaired by the Lead Department Representative) where reps and staff prioritise improvements. 
- Use staff office hours and end-of-term MEQs to provide input that reps take forward (e.g., SSCCs, Annual Student Experience Review, CS student hub). 
- Note: Office hours may not run every week—email relevant staff if none are advertised. 
Source: CS Student Partnership Committees & Academic Representatives | CS Student Intranet; Office Hours & Drop-in Sessions | CS Student Handbook; Chapter 9, Sections 6–7 | UCL Academic Manual.

Academic Representatives  
Academic Representatives are students' representatives in student matters; they are members of UCL standing committees, including the Staff Student Consultative Committee, contribute to the Annual Student Experience Review exercise, and coordinate activity within the CS student hub, the department's student voice and feedback platform. Academic Representatives will proactively seek out students' thoughts and opinions on their programme of study and their wider learning experience; present students' concerns and feedback to the department; communicate with students on an ongoing basis about their work with the department, and any positive changes made as a result; play an active role in the development and enhancement of their programme; and promote the value of students and staff working together to build a better education.  
Further information: - Chapter 9, Section 6.3: Academic Representation | UCL Academic Manual - Course Representatives | Students' Union UCL  
Admissions Tutor  
The Admissions Tutor is a member of the programme team who responsible for coordinating the process of admissions within a programme or programmes. This includes: setting admission targets and entry standards, monitoring student performance against entry standards, and confirming decisions to UCL Admissions. They act as the channel of communication with the Faculty Tutor and with the Head of Outreach and Admissions (Registry and Academic Services).  
Further information: - Chapter 12, Section 11: Responsibilities of the Admissions Tutor | UCL Academic Manual  
Affiliate and Ancillary Tutor

Prof. Daniel Alexander Head of Department  
Teaching and Learning Team welcome  
A warm welcome to our new students and welcome back to our returning students.  
We are very excited to have you with us this year and we're looking forward to supporting you through your time with us. We hope this handbook will serve as a useful companion on your academic journey: it sets out key contacts in the department, and the wide array of academic, pastoral, and welfare support options available to you as a UCL student. It also includes the broad framework of rules and regulations that govern our degrees.  
In addition to the handbook, your programme has a dedicated member of the Teaching and Learning Team who can advise you on a whole host of issues and can connect you with the best source of support. You will have met your Teaching and Learning Administrator during induction week, and you can find their details on the Teaching and Learning contact page.  
You have access to the Computer Science Student Intranet, which is a live space where you'll be able to connect with news, events, and current goings on around the department and faculty. The intranet will grow and evolve further as we better understand your needs, and we will work with you through your Student Representatives to get your input and make this a useful resource for all our students.  
A key contact for you during your time studying at UCL is your Student Representative. They are a fellow student on your degree programme and are there to present the views of your cohort. Through discussion and collaboration with staff in the department they aim to make your experience the best it can be. Find out more about them via the student intranet.
reference: The Student Representative at UCL acts as a fellow student on the degree programme who presents the views of their cohort and collaborates with staff in the department to improve the student experience. This role is crucial in connecting students, including student and staff entrepreneurs, with academic and administrative staff to ensure their needs and ideas are heard and supported. UCL fosters entrepreneurship through UCL Innovation & Enterprise, which offers training, advice, funding, competitions, and incubator space to help student and staff entrepreneurs start or grow their businesses. By working closely with the Student Representatives, the department ensures that entrepreneurial students receive relevant support and that their experiences contribute to shaping the academic environment and resources available to all students.

user_input: How does UCL Careers support Computer Science students in gaining practical experience through internships and placements, and how is this connected to the opportunities available at UCL East?
response:
UCL Careers supports CS students with one-to-one guidance, events, and internship/placement vacancy listings via myUCLCareers; I don't know how this connects to UCL East based on the handbook excerpts provided.
- Book a one-to-one with UCL Careers for help exploring options, applications/CVs, interviews, and assessment centres.
- Use myUCLCareers to find and apply for internships and attend UCL Careers recruitment fairs and events.
- Speak to the Computer Science Careers Tutor (Tigmanshu Bhatnagar) for advice on making the most of careers resources.
- For departmental experience, engage the Research Internships Tutor (summer research internships), the Year in Industry Tutor (EMY routes), and consider industry-linked projects via the Industry Exchange Network (IXN).
Note: UCL Careers services are available to current students and graduates for up to three years after course completion; optional internships/placements are not part of the programme.
Source: UCL careers; Computer Science careers; Optional internships and placements; Industrial collaboration & placements for final projects/ dissertations

UCL careers  
Information on UCL’s careers services for current students and recent graduates.  
UCL Careers provides a wide variety of careers information, one-to-one guidance and events for UCL students and recent graduates. UCL Careers assists them through the entire job hunting process, including exploring options, searching for vacancies, preparing CVs and applications, practicing for interviews, aptitude tests or assessment centres, and providing access to recruitment fairs and other employment-related events. They can also advise on exploring options for further study and funding. Services and events are available to all taught students, researchers (PhD students and postdocs) and graduates (for up to three years after course completion).  
UCL Careers also supports employability activities within departments such as work-related learning and internships.  
UCL students are helped with applications and sourcing opportunities with web resources and advice. They can book appointments and search for internship and graduate job vacancies via myUCLCareers.

Teaching Support Coordinator  
The Teaching Support Coordinator is responsible for managing teaching support across all programmes and for the effective running of teaching support work undertaken by research staff and PhD students. This includes maintaining current information about research staff teaching interests and abilities, organising appropriate training, allocating responsibilities in a fair and transparent way, and monitoring the running of the scheme. The Year in Industry Tutor is responsible for coordinating Extra Mural Year activity as part of BSc Computer Science (with Year in Industry), MEng Computer Science (with Year in Industry) and MEng Mathematical Computation (with Year in Industry) routes.

longer-term difficulties and UCL's normal mechanisms (e.g. Reasonable Adjustments, Extenuating Circumstances, Interruption of Study) are not providing enough support. We will work with you to put together a Support Plan to help you get the most out of your studies.

Industrial collaboration & placements for final projects/ dissertations  
Student projects may have an industrial focus, developed in collaboration with an approved industry partner via the department's Industry Exchange Network (IXN). Entrepreneurship at UCL  
Information on entrepreneurship and enterprise at UCL.  
UCL has a long and successful track record of supporting spin-outs and start-ups developed by its academic and student communities. Many of the student and staff entrepreneurs have won external awards and achieved substantial investment allowing their enterprises to grow and reach their full potential. UCL Innovation & Enterprise offers a wide range of support to students ranging from training programmes, advice on whether an idea has commercial potential, one-to-one sessions with business advisers, funding, competitions and incubator space to help them start or grow their business.

Specifically, students have access to a careers tutor within the department, Tigmanshu Bhatnagar, who offers guidance on making the most of UCL's careers resources. For practical experience, students can undertake optional internships during the summer between academic years, which are not part of the degree programme but provide valuable skills and experience. Additionally, the department offers paid research internships over the summer with research staff or teams. Students may also apply for a 'Year in Industry' to take a year-long placement with an approved industry partner, which formally extends the degree by one year. Final year projects and dissertations may involve industrial collaboration through the Industry Exchange Network, sometimes requiring on-site engagement. These employability and career development opportunities align with the broader context of UCL East, which is highlighted as the biggest development in UCL's history and is welcoming its second cohort of students. UCL East represents an exciting expansion of the university's multidisciplinary academic culture, providing a dynamic environment where students can shape their journey and benefit from enhanced educational and career-related opportunities.

user_input: How do the policies on summative assessments at UCL define the structure and feedback timelines for these assessments, and what specific provisions does the Computer Science department have regarding feedback and provisional marks?
response:
UCL requires feedback on summative assessments within one calendar month (plus up to one notified extra week), while Computer Science aims for 20 working days and releases coursework provisional marks (not for exams).

- Know the structure: examinations are short, fixed-time assessments under specific conditions; CS uses a numeric marking scale, with some components binary-marked or pass/fail.
- Timelines: expect feedback within one calendar month (UCL); CS taught modules aim for 20 working days; research/dissertation drafts get feedback in 10 working days if submitted ≥15 working days before the final deadline.
- Coursework: provisional marks usually come with feedback (sometimes feedback first); final marks are released by Student Registry Services after Board confirmation.
- Exams: no provisional marks; scripts are not returned; feedback is normally cohort-level rather than individual.
- If feedback is late, check the module’s Moodle forum for a notice; if none and the timeframe is exceeded, raise it with the module’s responsible Programme Director or notify the Departmental Tutor (or via your Course Rep); note feedback may be withheld until approved extensions end.

Source: UCL feedback policy; Computer Science feedback, exam script, and provisional marks policies; Section 5: Assessment Feedback (Examinations); Chapter 4 Section 3.7 Marking Scale.
retrieved_contexts:
UCL feedback policy  
It is UCL policy that all students receive feedback on summative assessments within one calendar month of the submission deadline. This feedback may take the form of indicative or provisional marks, written feedback, individual discussions, group discussions, marker’s answers, model answers or other solutions, although students should note that UCL is generally unable to return examination scripts.  
If, for whatever reason, a department/ division cannot ensure that the one calendar month deadline is met then they will tell students when the feedback will be provided, it is expected that the extra time needed should not exceed one week. Where feedback is not provided within the timescale, students should bring the matter to the attention of the module's responsible Programme Director.  
Computer Science feedback policy  
For taught modules, the department aims to release feedback for summative assessments within 20 working days of the date of the assessment/ submission deadline (i.e., excluding weekends, closure periods, and UK Bank Holidays). Feedback for some assessments may be withheld until any approved extensions have completed, i.e., to ensure no unfair advantage to students submitting later.  
For research project/ dissertation modules, the department aims to provide feedback on a draft version within 10 working days, provided the draft is received at least 15 working days prior to the final submission deadline.

The department will proactively monitor the return of feedback for Computer Science modules, and will take appropriate action where delays occur. Students should expect that any delay will be notified in advance via the module's Moodle forum. If this does not occur, students should notify the Departmental Tutor either directly or via their Course Representative.  
Computer Science exam script policy  
UCL is generally unable to return written examination scripts and will not do so as a means of providing feedback. Feedback on examinations should usually take the form of cohort-level feedback, which summarises general issues and areas for improvement based on the performance of the cohort. Individualised or highly detailed feedback is neither appropriate or possible for examinations.  
Computer Science provisional marks policy  
UCL permits departments to release provisional marks for assessments prior to their confirmation by the Board of Examiners. For coursework, provisional marks will usually be released alongside feedback on the assessment; sometimes feedback will be released first, and provisional marks will follow. For examinations, provisional marks will not be released, since the exams take place very close to the point confirmed results are published. In all cases, final marks will be released via Student Registry Services, following their confirmation by the Board of Examiners.  
Section 5: Assessment Feedback | UCL Academic Manual  
Examinations  
Information on written examinations and a link to the UCL Examination Guide for Candidates on the Examinations and Awards website.  
An examination is a short duration test-like assessment that is taken under specific conditions, usually at a fixed time, and which requires adherence to a strict code of practice.

Students are encouraged to contact the responsible examiner with any queries relating to how work will be marked or what is expected, either in class, via the Moodle discussion forum, or during Office Hours. In the event that assessment information is missing, incomplete, or unclear, students should contact the relevant examiner or Module leader, which should be via the module's Moodle discussion forum.  
Chapter 4, Section 2: Assessment Information | UCL Academic Manual  
Chapter 4, Section 4: Marking & Moderation | UCL Academic Manual  
Marking scales  
Computer Science operates a Numeric Marking Scale on its taught programmes of study, which means that each module is awarded a numerical mark (on a scale of 0.00 - 100.00) based on students' performance in that module's summative components of assessment.  
Some components are binary marked, which means that a genuine attempt will be awarded a mark of 100.00, otherwise the work will be given mark of 0.00. The aim of these assessments is to help students to learn but to relieve the pressure of chasing every mark.  
Some components may be designated as 'pass/ fail', which means that these do not attract a numerical mark but, instead, are given a binary pass/ fail grade. Such components do not contribute to the module's overall mark but, where used, are usually required to pass the module.  
Chapter 4, Section 3.7: Marking Scale | UCL Academic Manual  
Feedback  
Feedback and provisional marks  
Regular feedback is an essential part of every student’s learning. Students should expect to receive feedback throughout their studies in relation to their performance in both formative and summative assessments, including in relation to their draft final project/ dissertation.  
UCL feedback policy

More information on student feedback surveys is given in [Section 18 Student feedback and You Shape UCL | CS Student Handbook](

reference: At UCL, summative assessments are designed to evaluate students' achievement of a module's learning outcomes and contribute to their academic outcome. Each module has one or more summative components, each with a defined method, title, and weight, collectively known as the module's assessment pattern. Feedback on summative assessments is a key part of the learning process. UCL policy mandates that all students receive feedback within one calendar month of the submission deadline, which may include provisional marks, written feedback, discussions, or model answers. If delays occur, students are informed, and the extra time should not exceed one week. Specifically, the Computer Science department aims to release feedback within 20 working days of the assessment deadline, excluding weekends and holidays. Feedback may be withheld until approved extensions are completed to ensure fairness. For research projects or dissertations, draft feedback is provided within 10 working days if the draft is submitted at least 15 working days before the final deadline. The department monitors feedback return and notifies students of any delays via Moodle. Regarding provisional marks, Computer Science usually releases them alongside coursework feedback, but provisional marks are not released for examinations due to their proximity to final result publication. Final marks are confirmed and released via Student Registry Services after Board of Examiners approval.

user_input: How does the Computer Science Programming Tutoring Scheme support first-year students, and what benefits can Computer Science alumni access as part of the UCL alumni community?
response:
The scheme assigns every Year 1 student a small-group Programming Tutor to build proficiency in C, Haskell, Java, and Python 3, and graduates can access UCL Careers services for up to three years after course completion.
- At the start of the academic year, look out for your Programming Tutor assignment from the Senior Programming Tutors and join the small-group sessions.
- Use the tutoring to practice core languages (C, Haskell, Java, Python 3) and get help as you develop proficiency.
- As a recent graduate (within 3 years), book appointments and search internships/jobs via myUCLCareers, and attend UCL Careers guidance and events.
- For extra guidance, contact the department’s Computer Science Careers Tutor (Tigmanshu Bhatnagar) or use UCL Careers resources.

Note: UCL Careers services are available to graduates only up to three years after course completion.

Source: Programming tutoring; UCL careers
retrieved_contexts:
All Year 1 undergraduate students will be assigned a Programming Tutor at the start of the academic year as part of the Computer Science Programming Tutoring Scheme.  
The scheme is a student-led initiative wherein undergraduate students in Years 2-4 can apply to act as Programming Tutors to provide small-group support to students in Year 1 of their undergraduate studies. The scheme supports beginner programmers towards proficiency in languages such as C, Haskell, Java, and Python 3, and enables more advanced programmers to hone their skills. The scheme is coordinated by Senior Programming Tutors, who are responsible for recruiting and assigning Programming Tutors and for liaising with the department's staff.

Tutors will not be available every week, since all staff are required to take leave on occasion and will have competing demands on their time. However, staff will communicate their availability to their tutees.

The UCL Transition Programme supports new undergraduate first-year students at UCL, helping them to settle in quickly and achieve their potential. Each first-year student is assigned a Transition Mentor for Term 1. Transition mentors are later-year students within the department who work with small groups of students on a weekly basis to help them settle into UCL and London as well as focussing on academic issues and topics specific to their degree programme.  
First-year undergraduate students meet their Transition Mentor during the first week of term at the Meet your Mentor session, which is part of the scheduled programme of induction events.

UCL Careers provides a wide variety of careers information, one-to-one guidance and events for UCL students and recent graduates. UCL Careers assists them through the entire job hunting process, including exploring options, searching for vacancies, preparing CVs and applications, practicing for interviews, aptitude tests or assessment centres, and providing access to recruitment fairs and other employment-related events. External Examiner  
Each programme has an External Examiner who works with UCL's academic staff to ensure academic standards, consistency of practice, and fair treatment of students. The primary responsibilities of the External Examiner are to review summative assessment methods, to review a representative sample of summative marked work, and to submit an annual report, based upon their professional judgement, about the programme. The External Examiner will consider: whether the academic standards set for the programme qualifications are appropriate; the extent to which the assessment processes are rigorous, ensure equity of treatment for students and have been fairly conducted within UCL's regulations and guidance; the standards of student performance in the programme, or parts of programmes; and identify comparable practice.

reference: Academic Coordinators have distinct responsibilities depending on the level of study. The Academic Coordinator for Taught Postgraduate Programmes oversees the delivery, review, and development of postgraduate programmes, including reviewing student feedback, leading programme reviews, rationalising modules, ensuring coordination between programmes, and supporting the Departmental Tutor with postgraduate matters. Academic Coordinators for Undergraduate Programmes manage teaching and learning within a designated year of study, acting as academic leads for teaching staff, ensuring quality and coherence of teaching, coordinating coursework deadlines to avoid clustering, providing timely information and advice to students, and managing tutorial activities. These roles are crucial in maintaining academic standards and supporting students throughout their studies. Regarding academic misconduct, the department has clear regulations defining misconduct, such as unauthorized use or sharing of code, and a zero-tolerance approach to contract cheating. Investigations into suspected misconduct involve examiners reviewing originality and integrity of submitted work, potentially using tools like Turnitin or Measure of Software Similarity, and may include oral examinations or panels. Penalties for confirmed misconduct can range up to exclusion from UCL or rescindment of qualifications. Academic Coordinators, by overseeing programme delivery and student experience, play a key role in ensuring students are informed about academic integrity policies and in supporting the enforcement of these procedures within their programmes.

UCL's Student Support Framework  
Details of how UCL and the department will support students through their studies.  
About the UCL Student Support Framework  
UCL is committed to providing the support students need in order to make the most out of their studies. The Student Support Framework draws together our main academic support processes under one banner to help students understand the options open to them.  
UCL's Student Support Framework  
The Framework includes the following components:  
Part 1: How to Use this Framework  
Helps students find their way around the different support options open to them. It includes: - Where to find help and advice - Information about when to use this framework (for example if you are an affiliate, study abroad or placement student) - Advice on confidentiality and how UCL will look after student data - Information on providing supporting evidence - Links to other support options that are available to students.  
Part 2: Types of Support explains how each of the following processes works:

Academic advice on specific modules  
For advice about a specific module, for example relating to its syllabus, learning outcomes, prerequisite conditions, or self-assessment of suitability, students should contact the Module Leader or general contact, whose contact details are set out in the UCL Module Catalogue.  
Administrative advice and troubleshooting  
If a student experiences any issues with making or confirming their module selections, they should contact their Programme Administrator.
reference: Academic references at UCL are personal statements usually provided by a Personal Tutor or Project Supervisor that detail a student's confirmed module results, provisional or conferred awards, and a summary of their achievements within their cohort. These references support applications for jobs or further study and should be requested well in advance, as they are typically only possible once results have been confirmed by the responsible Board of Examiners and may take several weeks to prepare, especially during busy periods. To assist students throughout their academic journey, the Teaching and Learning Team offers extensive support, including a dedicated member who can advise on various issues and connect students with appropriate resources. Students also have access to the Computer Science Student Intranet for news and events, and can engage with Student Representatives who present cohort views and collaborate with staff to enhance the student experience. The team is accessible via email, online drop-in sessions, or face-to-face appointments, ensuring students receive guidance and support when requesting academic references and navigating their studies at UCL.

user_input: What is the Computer Science feedback policy regarding the timeframe for releasing feedback on summative assessments, and how can students use the Computer Science X channel and Teaching and Learning Team drop-in sessions to address any concerns about delayed feedback?
response:
Computer Science aims to release feedback on summative assessments within 20 working days.

- Check your module’s Moodle forum for any announced delay; the department monitors returns and should notify you of delays.
- Note: UCL policy is one calendar month (with any extra time not exceeding one week if notified), and some feedback may be withheld until approved extensions have completed.
- If no announcement and the timescale has passed, notify the Departmental Tutor directly or via your Course Representative.
- Use the Teaching and Learning Team Drop-in (Term-time Thu 11:00–12:00 UK; MEng RAI Wed 10:00–11:00) with your Student ID to discuss the delay; follow the official Computer Science X channel for departmental updates.

Source: Computer Science feedback policy; UCL feedback policy; Teaching and Learning Team Drop-in Sessions; Social media
retrieved_contexts:
UCL feedback policy  
It is UCL policy that all students receive feedback on summative assessments within one calendar month of the submission deadline. This feedback may take the form of indicative or provisional marks, written feedback, individual discussions, group discussions, marker’s answers, model answers or other solutions, although students should note that UCL is generally unable to return examination scripts.  
If, for whatever reason, a department/ division cannot ensure that the one calendar month deadline is met then they will tell students when the feedback will be provided, it is expected that the extra time needed should not exceed one week. Where feedback is not provided within the timescale, students should bring the matter to the attention of the module's responsible Programme Director.  
Computer Science feedback policy  
For taught modules, the department aims to release feedback for summative assessments within 20 working days of the date of the assessment/ submission deadline (i.e., excluding weekends, closure periods, and UK Bank Holidays). Feedback for some assessments may be withheld until any approved extensions have completed, i.e., to ensure no unfair advantage to students submitting later.  
For research project/ dissertation modules, the department aims to provide feedback on a draft version within 10 working days, provided the draft is received at least 15 working days prior to the final submission deadline.

The department will proactively monitor the return of feedback for Computer Science modules, and will take appropriate action where delays occur. Students should expect that any delay will be notified in advance via the module's Moodle forum. If this does not occur, students should notify the Departmental Tutor either directly or via their Course Representative.  
Computer Science exam script policy  
UCL is generally unable to return written examination scripts and will not do so as a means of providing feedback. Feedback on examinations should usually take the form of cohort-level feedback, which summarises general issues and areas for improvement based on the performance of the cohort. Individualised or highly detailed feedback is neither appropriate or possible for examinations.  
Computer Science provisional marks policy  
UCL permits departments to release provisional marks for assessments prior to their confirmation by the Board of Examiners. For coursework, provisional marks will usually be released alongside feedback on the assessment; sometimes feedback will be released first, and provisional marks will follow. For examinations, provisional marks will not be released, since the exams take place very close to the point confirmed results are published. In all cases, final marks will be released via Student Registry Services, following their confirmation by the Board of Examiners.  
Section 5: Assessment Feedback | UCL Academic Manual  
Examinations  
Information on written examinations and a link to the UCL Examination Guide for Candidates on the Examinations and Awards website.  
An examination is a short duration test-like assessment that is taken under specific conditions, usually at a fixed time, and which requires adherence to a strict code of practice.
