Staff office hours  
Each Programme Director and Module Leader will hold a regular office hour during term time (for modules this will be during the term in which the module is delivered.) These sessions are intended as informal drop-ins where students can raise any issues of concerns, ideas for improvement, or problems they may be experiencing. Students are welcome to attend these sessions without notification or appointment; most sessions operate a lobby-based queue system.  
Office hours will either be listed in the timetable or advertised to students by the responsible staff. The aim is for these sessions to run regularly, but they cannot be guaranteed to run every week. Students should feel free to contact the relevant staff by email where an office hour is not available.  
[Office Hours & Drop-in Sessions | CS Student Handbook](  
Surveys and questionnaires  
Students will be invited to provide feedback on their individual modules via Module Evaluative Questionnaires (MEQs) at the end of each term. These questionnaires ask about a students' learning experience, the resources and materials they have been provided with, the teaching they have received, and their views on what could be improved. More information on student feedback surveys is given in [Section 18 Student feedback and You Shape UCL | CS Student Handbook](  
Student forum

Computer Science is active on the following social media channels: - Computer Science X – the department's official X channel. - Computer Science YouTube –the department's YouTube channel. - Computer Science LinkedIn – the department's LinkedIn page.

How to stay safe when networking online | UCL Students  
Fraud and scams - Staying safe online | UCL Students  
Teaching and Learning Team Drop-in Sessions  
The Teaching and Learning team run a virtual drop-in session for student queries. The session runs in Teams. Although you do not need an appointment, you may need to wait if another student is already in the session. We encourage use of the drop-in, as it is often a quicker way of resolving a query than over email.  
Schedule  
Term-time, Wednesday 10am to 11am (UK time) ( This session is for MEng Robotics & Artificial Intelligence students only)  
Term-time, Thursday 11am to 12pm (UK time)  
You can join the drop-in using one of the buttons below. Please ensure you join the session appropriate to your programme of study.  
We operate a lobby-based queue system. You will remain in the queue until a member of the Teaching and Learning team is free to talk. When your conversation has concluded, we will ask you to exit the meeting so we can invite the next student in.  
Please have your Student ID ready when you join the drop-in. This helps us be more efficient in responding to your enquiry.  
You will only be able to speak to a staff member via the below links when the meetings are live.  
Important:  
There will be no Thursday drop-ins on 13 February, 20 March, and 10 April.

If feedback is delayed, students should be notified in advance via the module's Moodle forum. If no notification is given, students are advised to notify the Departmental Tutor directly or through their Course Representative. Information on module feedback, including when they occur and why they are important.  
Throughout all modules students will be asked to answer short pulse survey questions, on a regular basis.  
These pulse surveys are important because it helps teaching staff 'check-in' with students, making sure that they can understand and access key aspects such as the content of the module, assessment information and learning resources. This provides an opportunity for students to reflect on their learning and also give constructive feedback by engaging in a dialogue with staff about the results. Helpful comments and ideas from students mean that changes and improvements can be made to the module before it ends, as well as shaping the module for future students.  
UCL Changemakers  
Information on the UCL ChangeMakers scheme and how students can get involved.  
UCL ChangeMakers helps students and staff work in partnership to make education better at UCL: - Students and staff can apply for funding to collaborate on a project focused on enhancing education and students' experience at UCL. - Projects address issues that are important to students, often uncovered through student survey data, discussed at Student Partnership Committees, raised through Unitu or as the result of ideas from students and/or staff. - Students are recognised for their contribution to enhancing education at UCL through the payment of a stipend. - There are two application deadlines a year, in terms 1 and 2.  
Projects are open to all students: undergraduate, postgraduate taught and postgraduate research (MRes).

Volunteering Services  
Information about the Students' Union UCL Volunteering Services and how to become involved.  
About Volunteering Services, who they are and how a student can find out more or become involved  
The Volunteering Service at Students' Union UCL exists to connect UCL students with London's Voluntary and Community Sector, primarily through volunteering. It's one of the largest volunteering teams in UK Higher Education, meaning that UCL students have access to opportunities that their peers in other universities often do not.  
The Service runs three main programmes: - Partnerships linking students with volunteering opportunities within their network of around 350 community partners. - Student-led Projects supporting students to set up and run their own community projects. - Community Research Initiative connecting master's students with community organisations for collaborative research and Knowledge Exchange projects that form their dissertations.  
Through community volunteering, students develop new skills and learn how to enact change in the wider world. UCL Student volunteers also report positive benefits on their academic study and well-being.  
The Volunteering Service's opportunities can be found on its online directory, where students can search for roles related to their academic studies, by skills developed or by cause. There are plenty of one-off and flexible vacancies that students can fit around their studies and other commitments.
reference: The UCL ChangeMakers scheme supports students by enabling them to collaborate with staff on projects aimed at enhancing education and the student experience at UCL. Students can apply for funding, work on issues important to them, and receive a stipend for their contributions. This scheme is open to all students, including undergraduates and postgraduates. On the other hand, UCL Careers services are available to both current students and alumni for up to three years after graduation, providing career support and professional development opportunities. Together, these initiatives complement each other by offering students practical involvement in improving education through ChangeMakers while also providing career guidance and lifelong learning resources through UCL Careers services, thereby supporting students and alumni throughout their academic and professional journeys.

user_input: How can an international student at UCL utilize the Student Enquiries Centre and the Student Representative to address visa-related concerns and improve their overall student experience?
response:
Use UCL Students’ immigration guidance for visa queries and work with your Academic Representative/SPC to escalate broader issues and improve your experience.
- Review Immigration and visas | UCL Students and Student visa responsibilities | UCL Students for rules, support, and next steps.
- If visa problems affect assessments, submit an application under the Short-term Illness and Extenuating Circumstances procedure.
- Contact your Academic Representative to present concerns and ask them to raise them at the Student Partnership Committee or Staff Student Consultative Committee.

user_input: What is the Computer Science feedback policy regarding the timing and format of feedback on summative assessments, and how can students access additional support or information through the department's YouTube channel and drop-in sessions?
response:
Computer Science aims to return summative-assessment feedback within 20 working days (UCL: within one calendar month), in formats such as written comments, discussions, marker/model answers, and (for coursework) provisional marks; exam feedback is cohort-level only and scripts are not returned.
- For coursework, check Moodle for feedback (provisional marks usually released with it); final marks come via Student Registry Services; note feedback may be withheld until any approved extensions finish.
- If feedback is delayed, look for a Moodle forum notice; if none, notify the Departmental Tutor or raise via your Course Representative, and escalate to the Programme Director if outside UCL’s timescale.
- Join the Teaching and Learning Team virtual drop-in on Teams (term-time: Thu 11:00–12:00 UK; MEng RAI: Wed 10:00–11:00); have your Student ID; join the correct programme room; no Thursday drop-ins on 13 Feb, 20 Mar, 10 Apr.
- For additional information, follow the department’s YouTube channel; you can also use Programme Director/Module Leader office hours advertised locally.

Source: Computer Science feedback policy; UCL feedback policy; Computer Science exam script policy; Computer Science provisional marks policy; Teaching and Learning Team Drop-in Sessions; Social media
retrieved_contexts:
UCL feedback policy  
It is UCL policy that all students receive feedback on summative assessments within one calendar month of the submission deadline. This feedback may take the form of indicative or provisional marks, written feedback, individual discussions, group discussions, marker’s answers, model answers or other solutions, although students should note that UCL is generally unable to return examination scripts.  
If, for whatever reason, a department/ division cannot ensure that the one calendar month deadline is met then they will tell students when the feedback will be provided, it is expected that the extra time needed should not exceed one week. Where feedback is not provided within the timescale, students should bring the matter to the attention of the module's responsible Programme Director.  
Computer Science feedback policy  
For taught modules, the department aims to release feedback for summative assessments within 20 working days of the date of the assessment/ submission deadline (i.e., excluding weekends, closure periods, and UK Bank Holidays). Feedback for some assessments may be withheld until any approved extensions have completed, i.e., to ensure no unfair advantage to students submitting later.  
For research project/ dissertation modules, the department aims to provide feedback on a draft version within 10 working days, provided the draft is received at least 15 working days prior to the final submission deadline.

The department will proactively monitor the return of feedback for Computer Science modules, and will take appropriate action where delays occur. Students should expect that any delay will be notified in advance via the module's Moodle forum. If this does not occur, students should notify the Departmental Tutor either directly or via their Course Representative.  
Computer Science exam script policy  
UCL is generally unable to return written examination scripts and will not do so as a means of providing feedback. Feedback on examinations should usually take the form of cohort-level feedback, which summarises general issues and areas for improvement based on the performance of the cohort. Individualised or highly detailed feedback is neither appropriate or possible for examinations.  
Computer Science provisional marks policy  
UCL permits departments to release provisional marks for assessments prior to their confirmation by the Board of Examiners. For coursework, provisional marks will usually be released alongside feedback on the assessment; sometimes feedback will be released first, and provisional marks will follow. For examinations, provisional marks will not be released, since the exams take place very close to the point confirmed results are published. In all cases, final marks will be released via Student Registry Services, following their confirmation by the Board of Examiners.

Examinations  
Information on written examinations and a link to the UCL Examination Guide for Candidates on the Examinations and Awards website.  
An examination is a short duration test-like assessment that is taken under specific conditions, usually at a fixed time, and which requires adherence to a strict code of practice.

Although you do not need an appointment, you may need to wait if another student is already in the session. We encourage use of the drop-in, as it is often a quicker way of resolving a query than over email.  
Schedule

You can join the drop-in using one of the buttons below. Please ensure you join the session appropriate to your programme of study.

If feedback is delayed beyond the expected timeframe, students will be notified via the module's Moodle forum, and they should contact the Departmental Tutor or Course Representative if no notification is given. user_input: How do UCL Careers services support both current students and recent graduates, and what specific benefits related to careers and employability are available to UCL alumni through the UCL Careers platform?
response:
UCL Careers supports students and recent graduates with one-to-one guidance, resources, events, and vacancy search; alumni can use UCL Careers for up to three years and access UCL Connect professional development.

- Use myUCLCareers to book careers appointments and search internship/graduate vacancies.  
- Attend UCL Careers events, recruitment fairs, and workshops; get help with CVs, applications, interviews, aptitude tests, and assessment centres; seek advice on further study and funding.  
- Contact the Computer Science Careers Tutor (Tigmanshu Bhatnagar) for department-specific guidance and employability activities (e.g., work-related learning and internships).  
- As alumni, continue using UCL Careers services for up to three years after course completion and engage with UCL Connect panels, workshops, blogs, case studies and podcasts.

Caveat: Graduate access to UCL Careers is time-limited to three years after course completion; services apply to taught students, researchers, and graduates.

Source: UCL careers; UCL Alumni community

UCL careers  
Information on UCL’s careers services for current students and recent graduates.  
UCL Careers provides a wide variety of careers information, one-to-one guidance and events for UCL students and recent graduates. UCL Careers assists them through the entire job hunting process, including exploring options, searching for vacancies, preparing CVs and applications, practicing for interviews, aptitude tests or assessment centres, and providing access to recruitment fairs and other employment-related events. They can also advise on exploring options for further study and funding. Services and events are available to all taught students, researchers (PhD students and postdocs) and graduates (for up to three years after course completion).  
UCL Careers also supports employability activities within departments such as work-related learning and internships.

UCL Alumni community  
Information on UCL and Computer Science alumni activities.  
An alumnus (plural alumni) is a term for someone who has attended or graduated from a particular institution.  
As UCL alumni, students join a global community of over 350,000 former students. All UCL alumni can take advantage of a huge range of exclusive benefits and support, including access to thousands of e-journals, use of the library, a UCL-branded email for life and UCL Careers services for up to three years. Alumni can stay connected through reunions, international networks, and interest-based groups. UCL students and alumni can also take advantage of UCL's lifelong learning opportunities through UCL Connect, our professional development programme of panel events, workshops, and resources such as blogs, case studies and podcasts.

Alumni of the department | UCL Computer Science

Volunteering Services  
Information about the Students' Union UCL Volunteering Services and how to become involved.  
About Volunteering Services, who they are and how a student can find out more or become involved  
The Volunteering Service at Students' Union UCL exists to connect UCL students with London's Voluntary and Community Sector, primarily through volunteering. It's one of the largest volunteering teams in UK Higher Education, meaning that UCL students have access to opportunities that their peers in other universities often do not.  
The Service runs three main programmes: - Partnerships linking students with volunteering opportunities within their network of around 350 community partners. - Student-led Projects supporting students to set up and run their own community projects. - Community Research Initiative connecting master's students with community organisations for collaborative research and Knowledge Exchange projects that form their dissertations.  
Through community volunteering, students develop new skills and learn how to enact change in the wider world. UCL Student volunteers also report positive benefits on their academic study and well-being.  
The Volunteering Service's opportunities can be found on its online directory, where students can search for roles related to their academic studies, by skills developed or by cause. There are plenty of one-off and flexible vacancies that students can fit around their studies and other commitments.

This comprehensive support helps alumni stay connected and enhances their employability and career development.

retrieved_contexts:
All Year 1 undergraduate students will be assigned a Programming Tutor at the start of the academic year as part of the Computer Science Programming Tutoring Scheme.  
The scheme is a student-led initiative wherein undergraduate students in Years 2-4 can apply to act as Programming Tutors to provide small-group support to students in Year 1 of their undergraduate studies. The scheme supports beginner programmers towards proficiency in languages such as C, Haskell, Java, and Python 3, and enables more advanced programmers to hone their skills. The scheme is coordinated by Senior Programming Tutors, who are responsible for recruiting and assigning Programming Tutors and for liaising with the department's staff.

Tutors will not be available every week, since all staff are required to take leave on occasion and will have competing demands on their time. However, staff will communicate their availability to their tutees.

The UCL Transition Programme supports new undergraduate first-year students at UCL, helping them to settle in quickly and achieve their potential. Each first-year student is assigned a Transition Mentor for Term 1. Transition mentors are later-year students within the department who work with small groups of students on a weekly basis to help them settle into UCL and London as well as focussing on academic issues and topics specific to their degree programme.  
First-year undergraduate students meet their Transition Mentor during the first week of term at the Meet your Mentor session, which is part of the scheduled programme of induction events.

user_input: How do the assessment schedules for Computer Science modules align with the resources and support available through the Computer Science Student Intranet and Teaching and Learning Team?
response:
Assessment schedules are set and published on each module’s Moodle page (T1 weeks 6–20, T2 weeks 21–32), with support available from the Teaching and Learning Team (contacts on the CS Student Intranet).
- Check your module’s Moodle Assessment section for task instructions, marking criteria, and exact deadlines (default 4:00pm UK time).
- Follow the specified digital submission method, file formats, and any group-work protocols stated by the examiner.
- Post coursework questions on the Moodle discussion forum or contact the staff member who set the task; follow any expectations set by the Module Leader.
- For programme/module admin support (records, changes of status, module selection) and general guidance, use the Computer Science Teaching and Learning Contacts page on the CS Student Intranet.
- If the Module Catalogue differs, rely on Moodle and Module Leader announcements; reassessment details (which may use alternative methods) will be sent before late summer.
- Caveat: 4:00pm UK deadline applies even with Extenuating Circumstances extensions unless otherwise stated.

user_input: How does the Computer Science Programming Tutoring Scheme complement the resources available on the Computer Science Student Intranet to support new undergraduate students?
response:
It complements the CS Student Intranet by giving every Year 1 student assigned, peer‑led small‑group programming practice and guidance alongside intranet information and contacts.

- At the start of the year, attend sessions with your assigned Programming Tutor to build proficiency in C, Haskell, Java, and Python 3.
- Use the CS Student Intranet to find Teaching and Learning Team contacts for programme/admin queries beyond coding help.
- In Term 1, also attend weekly meetings with your Transition Mentor for settling‑in support and academic guidance.
- Note: Tutors may not be available every week; they will communicate their availability to you.

Source: Programming tutoring; Transition mentoring; Professional services teaching and learning team

All Year 1 undergraduate students will be assigned a Programming Tutor at the start of the academic year as part of the Computer Science Programming Tutoring Scheme.  
The scheme is a student-led initiative wherein undergraduate students in Years 2-4 can apply to act as Programming Tutors to provide small-group support to students in Year 1 of their undergraduate studies. The scheme supports beginner programmers towards proficiency in languages such as C, Haskell, Java, and Python 3, and enables more advanced programmers to hone their skills. The scheme is coordinated by Senior Programming Tutors, who are responsible for recruiting and assigning Programming Tutors and for liaising with the department's staff.

Tutors will not be available every week, since all staff are required to take leave on occasion and will have competing demands on their time. However, staff will communicate their availability to their tutees.

user_input: Could you explain how the Department of Computer Science's teaching programmes and module assessments are structured throughout the academic year, including key term dates and assessment periods?
response:
Computer Science modules run with coursework windows in Weeks 6–20 (Term 1) and Weeks 21–32 (Term 2), with assessments set and detailed on each module’s Moodle page and any reassessments in the late summer period.

- Check your module’s Moodle “Assessment” section for tasks, criteria, and deadlines; final assessment pattern is shown there.
- Note all coursework deadlines are at 4:00pm (UK time) and are published on Moodle.
- Raise coursework queries via the module’s Moodle discussion forum (or as the Module Leader directs) or contact the staff member who set the task.
- Submit CS coursework digitally (unless stated otherwise) and follow any specified formats, naming conventions, and group-work protocols.
- If reassessment is required, await details; methods may differ from the original and will be notified before the late summer assessment period.

Warning: Intended patterns appear in the UCL Module Catalogue, but approved changes may occur; rely on Moodle for the final pattern. Extensions go via Extenuating Circumstances but still use a 4:00pm (UK) deadline time.

Source: Chapter 4, Section 3: Module Assessment | Assessment tasks and their deadlines; Coursework scheduling and submission

Each module/ module delivery has a fixed upper limit on the number of places available (known as the 'module cap'), based on the department's teaching capacity and other resource constraints.  
Students are guaranteed a place on any modules that are compulsory on their programme/ year of study. However, places cannot be guaranteed on modules that are optional and elective, as availability will depend on how many places are left once any compulsory places have been assigned (i.e. a module that is optional on their programme may be compulsory on another.) Therefore, places will usually be allocated in the following order of priority: - Students for whom the module is compulsory (guaranteed a place.) - Students for whom the module is optional. - Students for whom the module is elective.  
Within those tiers, places will by default be allocated first to Computer Science students and then to non-Computer Science students on a first-come-first-serve basis within each group. If a student selects an optional or elective module that has no capacity remaining, is not formally available to them, or for which they do not satisfy any prerequisites, then their selection will be rejected, and they will be asked to select an alternative module.  
All module selections are ultimately subject to approval by the Module Leader and Programme Director.  
Overlapping content & re-registering on the same module  
Students must not select as optional or elective any module they have already taken, either in their current programme or during any prior studies. For example, if a module is available as an option in multiple terms or years of a programme, it can only be taken and passed once.
reference: The Department of Computer Science at UCL offers a portfolio of taught programmes designed to engage students and equip them with skills to address global challenges. These programmes have evolved alongside the department's growth and reflect contemporary computer science. Modules are delivered across the academic year, with assessments typically including coursework such as online or class tests, oral exams, presentations, and practical assessments. For Computer Science modules, coursework assessments are usually submitted during the term in which the module is delivered, plus an additional two to three weeks. Term 1 modules are assessed from Week 6 to Week 20, and Term 2 modules from Week 21 to Week 32. Examinations for these modules take place between 29 April and 30 May 2025. The academic year is divided into three terms: Term 1 runs from 23 September 2024 to 13 December 2024, Term 2 from 13 January 2025 to 28 March 2025, and Term 3 from 28 April 2025 to 13 June 2025. Reading weeks occur during the weeks beginning 4 November 2024 and 17 February 2025. The department carefully manages assessment dates to consider students' workloads, and deadlines are not set during closure periods, weekends, or UK bank holidays. Final year projects and dissertations have assessment periods to be confirmed. This structure ensures that teaching programmes and module assessments are well integrated with the academic calendar and provide clear timelines for students.

user_input: How do the Student Partnership Committee and Student Quality Reviewers schemes at UCL complement each other in enhancing the student educational experience?
response:
They complement each other by using SPCs to surface and prioritise issues locally while Student Quality Reviewers conduct in‑depth reviews and co‑design improvements to programmes, assessments, teaching, and curriculum.

- In early October, stand for (or support) Academic Representative elections and participate in your department’s SPC (UG/PG) to raise and prioritise concerns with staff.
- Gather evidence via staff office hours, pulse surveys, and MEQs, and bring this to SPC discussions.
- Apply to the Student Quality Reviewer scheme to: join Internal Quality Review panels, take Programme or Assessment Design Student Partner roles, work on ChangeMakers Teaching Dialogue, or act as a Student Curriculum Partner (paid £300 for ~25 hours).
- Use SPC priorities to shape SQR activities, and feed SQR findings and recommendations back to SPC for departmental action.

Caveat: SPCs meet at least three times a year; office hours may not run every week—email staff if no session is available.

Source: Departmental Student Partnership Committee; Student Quality Reviewers; Elections; Staff office hours; Surveys and questionnaires; UCL ChangeMakers
retrieved_contexts:
Student Quality Reviewers  
Information on what Student Quality Reviewers are and how students can get involved.  
Student Quality Reviewers, where UCL students take an in-depth look at different areas of education and provide detailed feedback and analysis from a student perspective.  
Through the Student Quality Reviewer scheme, students can: - Act as a member of an Internal Quality Review panel; - Take on a role to review new programmes or support enhancements to assessments through the Programme or Assessment Design Student Partner roles; - Work with staff to reflect on their teaching through the ChangeMakers Teaching Dialogue scheme; - Provide a student view on how teaching can include more diverse perspectives as a Student Curriculum Partner; - Students are paid a stipend of £300 for around 25 hours work.

Elections  
Academic Representatives are appointed during early October. If a student takes up a representative role, the Students' Union will work closely with them to provide training, support, and advice, and they'll be able to change the experience of everyone on their course or in their department for the better. Even if a student doesn't want to take up a role, they should keep an eye out for a chance to vote for which students they feel will do the best job.  
[CS Student Partnership Committees & Academic Representatives | CS Student Intranet](  
Academic Representatives | Students' Union UCL  
Find your representative | Students' Union UCL  
Chapter 9, Section 6: Student Academic Representation | UCL Academic Manual  
Departmental Student Partnership Committee  
Information on the role of the Departmental Student Partnership Committee.  
Every department at UCL has a Student Partnership Committee (SPC) that meets at least three times a year. Student Partnership Committees are meetings where Academic Reps and staff work together to develop solutions to students' concerns, and prioritise areas for improvement. SPCs are co-chaired by your Lead Department Representative. Some departments have a single SPC, while others split this into different levels of study. Most commonly, departments operate both an undergraduate and postgraduate SPC.  
[CS Student Partnership Committees & Academic Representatives | CS Student Intranet](  
Chapter 9, Section 6.4: Staff Student Consultative Committees | UCL Academic Manual  
Chapter 9, Section 7: Student Representation on UCL Academic Standing Committees and Sub-Committees | UCL Academic Manual  
Student voice - other ways to feed back

Chapter 9, Section 7: Student Representation on UCL Academic Standing Committees and Sub-Committees | UCL Academic Manual  
Student voice - other ways to feed back  
Other ways (specific to the department/ programme) that students can give feedback, including local processes and key contacts.  
Staff office hours  
Each Programme Director and Module Leader will hold a regular office hour during term time (for modules this will be during the term in which the module is delivered.) These sessions are intended as informal drop-ins where students can raise any issues of concerns, ideas for improvement, or problems they may be experiencing. Students are welcome to attend these sessions without notification or appointment; most sessions operate a lobby-based queue system.  
Office hours will either be listed in the timetable or advertised to students by the responsible staff. The aim is for these sessions to run regularly, but they cannot be guaranteed to run every week. Students should feel free to contact the relevant staff by email where an office hour is not available.  
[Office Hours & Drop-in Sessions | CS Student Handbook](  
Surveys and questionnaires  
Students will be invited to provide feedback on their individual modules via Module Evaluative Questionnaires (MEQs) at the end of each term. These questionnaires ask about a students' learning experience, the resources and materials they have been provided with, the teaching they have received, and their views on what could be improved. More information on student feedback surveys is given in [Section 18 Student feedback and You Shape UCL | CS Student Handbook](  
Student forum

Information on module feedback, including when they occur and why they are important.  
Throughout all modules students will be asked to answer short pulse survey questions, on a regular basis.  
These pulse surveys are important because it helps teaching staff 'check-in' with students, making sure that they can understand and access key aspects such as the content of the module, assessment information and learning resources. This provides an opportunity for students to reflect on their learning and also give constructive feedback by engaging in a dialogue with staff about the results. Helpful comments and ideas from students mean that changes and improvements can be made to the module before it ends, as well as shaping the module for future students.  
UCL Changemakers  
Information on the UCL ChangeMakers scheme and how students can get involved.  
UCL ChangeMakers helps students and staff work in partnership to make education better at UCL: - Students and staff can apply for funding to collaborate on a project focused on enhancing education and students' experience at UCL. - Projects address issues that are important to students, often uncovered through student survey data, discussed at Student Partnership Committees, raised through Unitu or as the result of ideas from students and/or staff. - Students are recognised for their contribution to enhancing education at UCL through the payment of a stipend. - There are two application deadlines a year, in terms 1 and 2.  
Projects are open to all students: undergraduate, postgraduate taught and postgraduate research (MRes).  
Student Quality Reviewers  
Information on what Student Quality Reviewers are and how students can get involved.
reference: The Student Partnership Committee (SPC) at UCL is a departmental forum where Academic Representatives and staff collaborate to address student concerns and prioritize improvements, meeting at least three times a year and co-chaired by the Lead Department Representative. This committee focuses on developing solutions to issues raised by students within their departments. Complementing this, the Student Quality Reviewers scheme involves UCL students taking an in-depth look at various areas of education by providing detailed feedback and analysis from a student perspective. Student Quality Reviewers participate in activities such as serving on Internal Quality Review panels, reviewing new programmes, supporting assessment enhancements, engaging in teaching dialogues, and contributing to curriculum diversity. Both schemes actively involve students in shaping and improving education at UCL, with the SPC focusing on ongoing departmental collaboration and the Student Quality Reviewers providing structured, detailed evaluations and feedback, often supported by stipends for their contributions. Together, they create a comprehensive approach to enhancing the student educational experience through partnership and quality assurance.

user_input: How should a student approach a programme transfer at UCL, and what role does the Programme Administrator play in supporting changes to registration status?
response:
Discuss the transfer with your tutor and both departments, then submit a formal request via Portico by the deadline; the Programme Administrator provides procedural guidance and SLC processing but not academic advice.

- First discuss plans with your Personal Tutor or Project/Dissertation Supervisor and both departments to agree the transfer in principle.
- Read the relevant UCL Academic Manual sections and submit any request in advance of the effective date.
- Request the programme transfer via Portico (C2RS Home) by end of October for September-intake programmes; later transfers only if module choices are unaffected.
- For procedural questions and to request an SLC Change of Circumstance Form, contact the Programme Administrator (UG: cs.undergraduate-students@ucl.ac.uk; PGT: cs.pgt-students@ucl.ac.uk).

- Caveats: The Programme Administrator cannot advise on academic merits; SLC must be notified of any change in status.

Source: Changing programme; Changes to registration status; Key contacts for changes to programme registration status; Informing the Student Loans Company of changes to student status

Key contacts for changes to programme registration status  
If a student wishes to change their module selections, transfer to a different programme of study within UCL, interrupt their studies, or withdraw from their programme entirely, they should contact their Personal Tutor or Programme Director for advice and guidance in the first instance. The Programme Administrator (Undergraduate students should contact cs.undergraduate-students@ucl.ac.uk and Postgraduate Taught students should contact cs.pgt-students@ucl.ac.uk) is able to provide procedural advice, but cannot advise on the academic merits of a decision to change status.

Changes to registration status  
Information on how to interrupt study, change or withdraw from a programme.  
Changing registration status  
Students wishing to make changes to their programme registration status (for example, transferring programme, interrupting their studies, or withdrawing), should first discuss their plans with their Personal Tutor or Project/ Dissertation Supervisor who can explain the options available and help them make the right decision. Students should also ensure they read the relevant sections of the UCL Academic Manual before making any requests to change their academic record.  
Applications must be made in advance of the effective date of change.

Changing programme  
Students wishing to transfer from one UCL degree programme to another, must make a formal application. For programmes with a September intake, the deadline for a change of degree programme during the same academic session is the end of October (in order to be compatible with module selection deadlines). Later transfers may be possible where the transfer does not affect module selections.  
Students must discuss any proposed programme transfer with both departments before requesting a change of programme; once agreed in principle, students should request the programme transfer via Portico under the 'C2RS Home' menu by the deadline given in [Section 4: Key dates | CS Student Handbook](  
Study Abroad and Placement Years

Students who do then decide they wish to withdraw, must apply online via Portico and can access the 'Withdraw from your programme' form in the 'Change of Circumstances' section of 'My Studies'.

Informing the Student Loans Company of changes to student status  
If a student makes a change to their programme or registration status during the course of the academic year, it is important that the Student Loans Company (SLC) is notified. The SLC can then re-assess and update its records. Changes could include a student withdrawing from their academic programme, an interruption in studies or transferring to a new programme. The SLC must also be notified when there is a change in mode of study or when a student has returned from an interruption.  
If a student experiences a change of status, they must request for a Change of Circumstance Form to be submitted to the SLC on their behalf by the Faculty. Any queries should be directed in the first instance to the Programme Administrator.

Additionally, the Programme Administrator liaises with the Student Loans Company by submitting Change of Circumstance Forms on behalf of students when their registration status changes. However, while the Programme Administrator can advise on procedures, they do not provide academic advice regarding the merits of the transfer decision.

user_input: How does UCL support student wellbeing through its Student Support and Wellbeing services, and what role does the UCL Prevention of Bullying, Harassment and Sexual Misconduct Policy play in maintaining a safe and respectful environment for students?
response:
UCL supports wellbeing through its Student Support and Wellbeing services and maintains safety via its approach to preventing and responding to bullying, harassment, sexual misconduct and domestic abuse using Report and Support and specialist advisors.

- Contact UCL Student Support and Wellbeing for a wide range of wellbeing and safety services, and be proactive in engaging with support.
- Ask your Personal Tutor, Programme Director, or Programme Administrator to help you find the services that best suit your needs.
- Visit the Student Enquiries Centre (1st floor, Student Centre) for walk-in questions on your student record, visas, fees, study abroad, and support signposting.
- To address harmful behaviours, use UCL’s Report and Support to report anonymously or with contact details and request to speak to an advisor.
- Choose an appropriate advisor (e.g., Dignity Advisor, Crime Prevention and Personal Safety Advisor, Human Resources Business Manager if it’s about a member of staff, Student Casework Team, Independent Sexual Violence Advisors, or Student Support and Wellbeing).

Warnings: Reports are strictly confidential and shared only on a need-to-know basis; you can provide as much or as little detail as you wish.

Source: Student support and wellbeing; UCL’s approach to preventing and responding to harmful behaviours (Equity, Diversity & Inclusion)
retrieved_contexts:
If a student experiences any of these behaviours, they can report it and/ or access support. Students can request to be contacted by an advisor or they can report anonymously. With either option students can give as much or as little detail as they wish. The reports are strictly confidential and only shared on a need to know basis.  
Students can request to speak to all the following advisors: - Dignity Advisor - Crime Prevention and Personal Safety Advisor - Human Resources Business Manager (if it’s about a member of staff) - Student Casework Team - Independent Sexual Violence Advisors - Student Support and Wellbeing  
The department is committed to ensuring its staff and students are treated with dignity, and we strongly encourage students to report any instances of harassment or bullying they witness or experience.  
Support for students who have been affected by sexual violence and/ or domestic abuse  
UCL will do its utmost to support anyone who has been, or is being, affected by sexual violence and/or domestic abuse. If a student would like to talk to somebody at UCL, the Student Support and Wellbeing Team can offer advice on the support available both internally and externally.

Equity, Diversity & Inclusion | UCL Computer Science  
UCL’s approach to preventing and responding to harmful behaviours  
Information about UCL’s approach to preventing and responding to harmful behaviours.  
Bullying, harassment, sexual misconduct and/or domestic abuse  
Every student and member of staff has a right to work and study without experiencing harm. Bullying, harassment, sexual misconduct and/or domestic abuse of one member of our community by another or others is never ok. UCL is working to eradicate these issues and seeks to promotes an environment in which they are known to be unacceptable and where individuals have the confidence to raise concerns in the knowledge that they will be dealt with appropriately and fairly.  
To help with this, UCL has Report and Support, an on-line reporting tool where students can report any issues anonymously or with contact details request to speak to an advisor in order to make an informed decision about their options.  
Examples of unacceptable behaviour include, but are not limited to: - Intimidating, hostile, degrading, humiliating or offensive behaviour which has the purpose or effect of violating a person’s dignity or creating an intimidating environment. - Unwanted conduct related to a protected characteristic that has the purpose or effect of violating a person’s dignity. The unwanted conduct can be physical, verbal, or non-verbal. - Unacceptable behaviour of a sexual nature such as sexual harassment, invitations, comments, coercion and promised advancement in exchange for sexual access.

Student support and wellbeing  
Information regarding central wellbeing and support services, including what services are offered, locations and contact information.  
Support services  
UCL Student Support and Wellbeing  
UCL is committed to the wellbeing and safety of its students and tries to give assistance wherever possible to ensure that studying at UCL is a fulfilling, healthy and enjoyable experience. There are a wide range of Student Support and Wellbeing Services available.  
Students should be aware that, while there are many services on offer, it is their responsibility to seek out support and they need to be proactive in engaging with the available services. Their Personal Tutor, Programme Director, and Programme Administrator can help them find the support services that best suit their needs.  
The Student Enquiries Centre  
The Student Enquiries Centre (SEC) have a physical space that students can visit for walk-in questions and enquiries on the 1st floor of the Student Centre. They can assist students with questions or concerns they may have around their student record and give guidance and information on a range of areas such as Visa, Fees, Study Abroad, Student Support Wellbeing or any matters regarding studies at UCL.

longer-term difficulties and UCL's normal mechanisms (e.g. Reasonable Adjustments, Extenuating Circumstances, Interruption of Study) are not providing enough support. We will work with you to put together a Support Plan to help you get the most out of your studies.
reference: UCL supports student wellbeing through a wide range of Student Support and Wellbeing services designed to ensure that studying at UCL is a fulfilling, healthy, and enjoyable experience. Students are encouraged to proactively engage with these services, which include assistance from Personal Tutors, Programme Directors, and Programme Administrators to find the most suitable support. The Student Enquiries Centre (SEC) offers walk-in, telephone, and online services to help with enquiries related to student records, wellbeing, and other study-related matters. The SEC operates during term-time with specific hours for walk-in and telephone support, and students can also use self-service options such as askUCL and Portico for efficient access to information and documentation. Complementing these support services, UCL maintains the Prevention of Bullying, Harassment and Sexual Misconduct Policy, which is part of the university's broader expectations of student conduct. This policy helps maintain a safe and respectful environment by setting clear standards against inappropriate behaviour, ensuring that students understand their responsibilities, and providing a framework for disciplinary action if necessary. Together, these services and policies contribute to a supportive and secure academic community at UCL.

user_input: What student support services are available at UCL to assist students with wellbeing concerns, and how does the UCL Prevention of Bullying, Harassment and Sexual Misconduct Policy relate to the university's expectations of student conduct?
response:
UCL provides Student Support and Wellbeing services and the Student Enquiries Centre, and its approach to preventing bullying/harassment/sexual misconduct sets the expectation that such behaviours are never acceptable and should be reported via Report and Support.

- Contact Student Support and Wellbeing for advice and support (including for sexual violence and/or domestic abuse).
- Use Report and Support to report concerns anonymously or request contact; you can ask to speak to advisors such as a Dignity Advisor, Crime Prevention and Personal Safety Advisor, HR Business Manager (if about staff), Student Casework Team, Independent Sexual Violence Advisors, or Student Support and Wellbeing.
- Visit the Student Enquiries Centre (1st floor, Student Centre) for walk‑in questions about your record, visas, fees, study abroad, or guidance on support services.
- If longer‑term difficulties persist beyond Reasonable Adjustments, Extenuating Circumstances, or Interruption of Study, ask the department to work with you on a Support Plan.

Caveats: Reports are confidential and shared only on a need‑to‑know basis; students are expected to proactively seek out and engage with support.

Source: Student support and wellbeing; Equity, Diversity & Inclusion – UCL’s approach to preventing and responding to harmful behaviours

user_input: Could you provide an overview of the Department of Computer Science at UCL, including its historical development and current departmental senior management contacts?
response:
UCL Computer Science began in the early 1970s, became an independent department in 1980 under Prof Peter Kirstein, and the current departmental senior management contacts are not provided in these excerpts. 
- For programme queries, email cs.undergraduate-students@ucl.ac.uk (UG) or cs.pgt-students@ucl.ac.uk (PGT). 
- Check the “Introduction to the department and faculty” section of the handbook for key contacts within the department and faculty. 
- For context, note the history: formed from Statistics & Computer Science in the 1970s; independent from 1980; REF 2014 ranked 1st in the UK for Computer Science. 
- If you need specific programme leadership, refer to the programme leadership listings in the handbook for named contacts. 
Source: Department of Computer Science and its history; Introduction to the department and faculty
retrieved_contexts:
UCL is a community of great minds. You are a valuable member of that community. I hope you will take every opportunity to shape your time with us, so that your experience is the best possible.  
Dr Michael Spence  
UCL President and Provost  
Head of Department's welcome  
Welcome to UCL's Department of Computer Science.  
Our discipline is set to produce the biggest technological advances of this century. It will have profound influence on life on Earth. It is all of you that will lead these advances. Our aim is to equip you to achieve that with skill, rigour, integrity, and a clear and complete understanding of how your work influences the world.  
It starts with the basics: understanding new concepts; solving problems; debugging code; writing reports. These are the skills that enable the sublime: revolutions in AI, healthcare, finance, media, the way we learn, work, and govern the country.

Introduction to the department and faculty  
An introduction to the department and its parent faculty, their relationship, and key contacts within both.  
Department of Computer Science and its history  
Computer Science was established at UCL in the early 1970s when the Department of Statistics was expanded to form a joint Department of Statistics and Computer Science. The initial nucleus of computer scientists came from the University of London Institute of Computer Science, which was renowned for its established MSc programme and for its research.  
In 1980 the independent Department of Computer Science was formed with Professor Peter Kirstein as its first Head. At that time there were seven academic staff (including three professors) and just one main research area: computer networks and data communications. Today, our portfolio of taught programmes has developed in line with the department's growth and reflects the leadingedge of contemporary computer science.  
In the 2014 Research Excellence Framework evaluation UCL was ranked in first place for Computer Science, out of 89 Universities assessed. 61% of its research work is rated as world-leading (the highest possible category) and 96% is rated as internationally excellent.  
Our teaching programmes are designed to engage students and give them the skills to address the world's challenges. We have pioneered new teaching methods for our undergraduates, and involve our postgraduates with our cutting-edge, highly rated academic research. The graduates we educate progress to a wide range of roles within engineering and technology sectors and beyond.  
Faculty of Engineering Sciences and its relationship with the department

reference: The Department of Computer Science at UCL was established in the early 1970s when the Department of Statistics was expanded to form a joint Department of Statistics and Computer Science. The initial group of computer scientists originated from the University of London Institute of Computer Science, known for its MSc programme and research. In 1980, the independent Department of Computer Science was formed with Professor Peter Kirstein as its first Head. At that time, there were seven academic staff members and one main research area: computer networks and data communications. Today, the department has grown significantly, offering a portfolio of taught programmes aligned with contemporary computer science and maintaining a leading research profile, as evidenced by UCL's first-place ranking in the 2014 Research Excellence Framework evaluation for Computer Science. The department works closely with the Faculty of Engineering Sciences to foster interdisciplinary research and teaching. Regarding departmental senior management, the Head of Department is Daniel Alexander, with Yvonne Rogers and Anthony Steed serving as Deputy Heads. Dariush Hosseini is the Director of Education, Lewis Griffin is the Departmental Tutor, and Simon Arridge is the Director of Research.

user_input: According to UCL's feedback policy, what are the expected timelines and forms of feedback for summative assessments in Computer Science, and how does Personal Tutoring support students in managing their academic progress during the term?
response:
Feedback on summative assessments is due within one calendar month (CS aims for 20 working days) in forms such as provisional marks, written/group feedback, model answers; I don't know about Personal Tutoring based on the handbook excerpts provided.
- Expect timelines to be posted on your module’s Moodle forum; if a department can’t meet the deadline, they should announce a new date (extra time ≤ one week).
- If feedback is late and no notice is given, raise it with the module’s responsible Programme Director and/or notify the Departmental Tutor (directly or via your Course Representative).
- For marking/expectation queries, contact the responsible examiner or Module Leader in class, via the module’s Moodle discussion forum, or during Office Hours.
- For research projects, submit a draft ≥15 working days before the final deadline to receive feedback within 10 working days.
- Caveats: Feedback may be withheld until approved extensions finish; exam scripts are not returned and exam feedback is cohort-level; coursework may have provisional marks with feedback, but exams do not; final marks are released by Student Registry Services after Board confirmation.

Source: UCL feedback policy; Computer Science feedback policy; Computer Science exam script policy; Computer Science provisional marks policy; Student forum; Staff office hours
retrieved_contexts:
UCL feedback policy  
It is UCL policy that all students receive feedback on summative assessments within one calendar month of the submission deadline. This feedback may take the form of indicative or provisional marks, written feedback, individual discussions, group discussions, marker’s answers, model answers or other solutions, although students should note that UCL is generally unable to return examination scripts.  
If, for whatever reason, a department/ division cannot ensure that the one calendar month deadline is met then they will tell students when the feedback will be provided, it is expected that the extra time needed should not exceed one week. Where feedback is not provided within the timescale, students should bring the matter to the attention of the module's responsible Programme Director.  
Computer Science feedback policy  
For taught modules, the department aims to release feedback for summative assessments within 20 working days of the date of the assessment/ submission deadline (i.e., excluding weekends, closure periods, and UK Bank Holidays). Feedback for some assessments may be withheld until any approved extensions have completed, i.e., to ensure no unfair advantage to students submitting later.  
For research project/ dissertation modules, the department aims to provide feedback on a draft version within 10 working days, provided the draft is received at least 15 working days prior to the final submission deadline.

The department will proactively monitor the return of feedback for Computer Science modules, and will take appropriate action where delays occur. Students should expect that any delay will be notified in advance via the module's Moodle forum. If this does not occur, students should notify the Departmental Tutor either directly or via their Course Representative.  
Computer Science exam script policy  
UCL is generally unable to return written examination scripts and will not do so as a means of providing feedback. Feedback on examinations should usually take the form of cohort-level feedback, which summarises general issues and areas for improvement based on the performance of the cohort. Individualised or highly detailed feedback is neither appropriate or possible for examinations.  
Computer Science provisional marks policy  
UCL permits departments to release provisional marks for assessments prior to their confirmation by the Board of Examiners. For coursework, provisional marks will usually be released alongside feedback on the assessment; sometimes feedback will be released first, and provisional marks will follow. For examinations, provisional marks will not be released, since the exams take place very close to the point confirmed results are published. In all cases, final marks will be released via Student Registry Services, following their confirmation by the Board of Examiners.  
Section 5: Assessment Feedback | UCL Academic Manual  
Examinations  
Information on written examinations and a link to the UCL Examination Guide for Candidates on the Examinations and Awards website.  
An examination is a short duration test-like assessment that is taken under specific conditions, usually at a fixed time, and which requires adherence to a strict code of practice.

Chapter 9, Section 7: Student Representation on UCL Academic Standing Committees and Sub-Committees | UCL Academic Manual  
Student voice - other ways to feed back  
Other ways (specific to the department/ programme) that students can give feedback, including local processes and key contacts.  
Staff office hours  
Each Programme Director and Module Leader will hold a regular office hour during term time (for modules this will be during the term in which the module is delivered.) These sessions are intended as informal drop-ins where students can raise any issues of concerns, ideas for improvement, or problems they may be experiencing. Students are welcome to attend these sessions without notification or appointment; most sessions operate a lobby-based queue system.  
Office hours will either be listed in the timetable or advertised to students by the responsible staff. The aim is for these sessions to run regularly, but they cannot be guaranteed to run every week. Students should feel free to contact the relevant staff by email where an office hour is not available.  
[Office Hours & Drop-in Sessions | CS Student Handbook](  
Surveys and questionnaires  
Students will be invited to provide feedback on their individual modules via Module Evaluative Questionnaires (MEQs) at the end of each term. These questionnaires ask about a students' learning experience, the resources and materials they have been provided with, the teaching they have received, and their views on what could be improved. More information on student feedback surveys is given in [Section 18 Student feedback and You Shape UCL | CS Student Handbook](  
Student forum

Students are encouraged to contact the responsible examiner with any queries relating to how work will be marked or what is expected, either in class, via the Moodle discussion forum, or during Office Hours. In the event that assessment information is missing, incomplete, or unclear, students should contact the relevant examiner or Module leader, which should be via the module's Moodle discussion forum.  
Chapter 4, Section 2: Assessment Information | UCL Academic Manual  
Chapter 4, Section 4: Marking & Moderation | UCL Academic Manual  
Marking scales  
Computer Science operates a Numeric Marking Scale on its taught programmes of study, which means that each module is awarded a numerical mark (on a scale of 0.00 - 100.00) based on students' performance in that module's summative components of assessment.  
Some components are binary marked, which means that a genuine attempt will be awarded a mark of 100.00, otherwise the work will be given mark of 0.00. The aim of these assessments is to help students to learn but to relieve the pressure of chasing every mark.  
Some components may be designated as 'pass/ fail', which means that these do not attract a numerical mark but, instead, are given a binary pass/ fail grade. Such components do not contribute to the module's overall mark but, where used, are usually required to pass the module.  
Chapter 4, Section 3.7: Marking Scale | UCL Academic Manual  
Feedback  
Feedback and provisional marks  
Regular feedback is an essential part of every student’s learning. Students should expect to receive feedback throughout their studies in relation to their performance in both formative and summative assessments, including in relation to their draft final project/ dissertation.  
UCL feedback policy
reference: UCL's feedback policy mandates that all students receive feedback on summative assessments within one calendar month of the submission deadline. Specifically, for Computer Science taught modules, the department aims to release feedback within 20 working days of the assessment or submission deadline, excluding weekends, closure periods, and UK Bank Holidays. Feedback may include indicative or provisional marks, written feedback, individual or group discussions, marker’s answers, model answers, or other solutions. However, examination scripts are generally not returned; instead, cohort-level feedback summarizing general issues and areas for improvement is provided. If feedback is delayed beyond the expected timeframe, students should notify the module's Programme Director or Departmental Tutor. Regarding Personal Tutoring, every undergraduate or taught postgraduate student is assigned a personal tutor who provides constructive academic and personal development guidance. Students are encouraged to engage proactively with their personal tutor, meeting at least once each term, to discuss academic progress and any issues. This relationship supports students in managing their studies effectively throughout the term.

user_input: How does the module selection process prioritize Computer Science students, and what benefits can these students expect to receive as part of the UCL Alumni community after graduation?
response:
Computer Science students are prioritized first within each selection tier (compulsory, optional, elective); I don't know based on the handbook excerpts provided what UCL Alumni benefits they receive.

- Check your programme diet on the Computer Science Student Intranet and choose modules accordingly.
- Register on Portico after (pre-/re-)enrolment and complete module registration by 11 October 2024.
- Monitor 'My Modules' on Portico for approvals; if a selection is rejected (e.g., no capacity or unmet requisites), choose an alternative from your diet.
- To change a selection, request via your home department; check the Module Selection Task on Portico for change deadlines; all changes need Module Leader and Programme Director approval.
- Note: places are capped; compulsory modules are guaranteed, but optional/elective places are allocated by priority and, within each tier, first to Computer Science students and then to non-Computer Science students on a first-come-first-serve basis.

Source: Module selection; Verification of selections
retrieved_contexts:
Module availability  
Modules for Computer Science students  
The programme diets for students on Computer Science programmes are set out on the Computer Science Student Intranet programme level pages. Students should pay attention to the specific rules and requirements for their programme, the modules available to them, and the volume of credit they must or may optionally take from any optional and elective groups.  
Modules for Ancillary students (non-Computer Science students)  
Ancillary students (i.e. those on a UCL programme at a department other than Computer Science) who wish to select Computer Science modules as optional, or elective, should refer to their own departments' programme pages for information on which modules are available to them. Ancillary students may only select Computer Science modules that are formally part of their programme's diet. If a module is compulsory for an Ancillary student, then they will be guaranteed a place, otherwise places will be allocated subject to remaining availability, the order of priority, the satisfaction of any requisite conditions, and final approval of the Module Leader and Programme Director.  
Modules for Affiliate students (Study Abroad, Erasmus, Exchange)  
Affiliate students (e.g. those on a Study Abroad, Erasmus, or Exchange programme) will be advised of the process for selecting modules by their home department. Modules may need to be selected before enrolment, or after arrival at UCL. Not all modules will be available to Affiliate students, particularly if a module's assessments would take place outside of the student's period of registration. Students should check with the relevant department to ensure they understand any restrictions and conditions.  
Computer Science | Study Abroad at UCL

Computer Science | Study Abroad at UCL  
Module registration for affiliates | UCL Students  
Module selection  
Choosing modules for 2024-25  
Students needing to select optional or elective modules, will be able to do so from before the start of the academic year. New students can register for modules once they have completed pre-enrolment. Continuing students can register for modules once they have completed re-enrolment.  
Students must complete module registration by no later than 11 October 2024, however they are strongly encouraged to complete the process as early as possible.  
Module selection | UCL Students  
Approval of selections  
Students can check the approval status of their module selections in the 'My Modules' area on Portico. Decisions will be notified by email when selections are either approved or declined. Where a selection is rejected, students will be informed of the reason for this and asked to select an appropriate alternative module from the programme diet, subject to the usual requisite conditions and approval process.  
Change of selections  
Students wishing to change a module selection, must make a request to their home department in the first instance. Any change will be subject to the same requisites, orders of priority, and restrictions as an initial selection and must be approved by the Programme Director and the Module Leader.  
Exact deadlines for making changes to module selections will be published each year in the 'Module Selection Task' on Portico.  
Verification of selections

Each module/ module delivery has a fixed upper limit on the number of places available (known as the 'module cap'), based on the department's teaching capacity and other resource constraints.  
Students are guaranteed a place on any modules that are compulsory on their programme/ year of study. However, places cannot be guaranteed on modules that are optional and elective, as availability will depend on how many places are left once any compulsory places have been assigned (i.e. a module that is optional on their programme may be compulsory on another.) Therefore, places will usually be allocated in the following order of priority: - Students for whom the module is compulsory (guaranteed a place.) - Students for whom the module is optional. - Students for whom the module is elective.  
Within those tiers, places will by default be allocated first to Computer Science students and then to non-Computer Science students on a first-come-first-serve basis within each group. If a student selects an optional or elective module that has no capacity remaining, is not formally available to them, or for which they do not satisfy any prerequisites, then their selection will be rejected, and they will be asked to select an alternative module.  
All module selections are ultimately subject to approval by the Module Leader and Programme Director.  
Overlapping content & re-registering on the same module  
Students must not select as optional or elective any module they have already taken, either in their current programme or during any prior studies. For example, if a module is available as an option in multiple terms or years of a programme, it can only be taken and passed once.

Students who have previously passed a module that is compulsory during a subsequent period of study (for example, if they took a module as an option on a BSc that is then compulsory on an MSc), then they must discuss this with their Programme Director in advance of module selection and agree a course of action.  
Section 2: Module Selection | UCL Academic Manual  
Section 2: Module Selection - Overlapping Content | UCL Academic Manual  
Module information  
Information about module syllabuses (i.e. their content, learning outcomes, and assessments) and timetabling of synchronous activity.  
A module's syllabus is a summary description of its academic content and how students' learning will be assessed. The syllabus may also include indicative learning outcomes, which describe what skills and knowledge students should be able to demonstrate on successful completion of the module. Students should review the syllabuses for their modules to help them make any optional and elective choices and to help contextualise their learning experience.  
Module catalogue  
Students can access current module syllabuses via the UCL Module Catalogue, which is a comprehensive directory of all modules across the whole of UCL, published in a consistent, searchable and accessible format. The content of syllabuses will vary across departments, but the catalogue aims to give students enough detail to make an informed decision about their module selections. Some Computer Science modules have published module introduction videos to help inform module selection.
reference: The module selection process at UCL prioritizes Computer Science students by allocating module places to them first, followed by non-Computer Science students on a first-come-first-serve basis within each group. If a student selects an optional or elective module that is full, unavailable, or for which they do not meet prerequisites, their selection will be rejected, and they must choose an alternative. All module selections require approval by the Module Leader and Programme Director. After graduation, Computer Science students become part of the UCL Alumni community, which includes over 350,000 former students globally. Alumni benefit from exclusive services such as access to thousands of e-journals, library use, a UCL-branded email for life, and UCL Careers services for up to three years. They can also stay connected through reunions, international networks, and interest groups, and participate in lifelong learning opportunities via UCL Connect, which offers professional development events, workshops, and resources.

user_input: How are module selections prioritized for Computer Science students, and what benefits does the UCL Alumni community offer to graduates from the Computer Science department?
response:
Compulsory modules are guaranteed; optional then elective places are allocated by priority and capacity, and CS alumni get e‑journals, library use, a UCL‑branded email for life, and up to three years of UCL Careers support.

- Select optional/elective modules on Portico as early as possible and by 11 October 2024 (after pre-/re-enrolment).
- Know the priority: compulsory (guaranteed) > optional > elective; within each tier, Computer Science students first, then non-CS, first‑come‑first‑served.
- Check approval in My Modules on Portico; you’ll be emailed when selections are approved/declined; if declined, pick an alternative from your programme diet.
- To change selections, request via your home department; changes need Programme Director and Module Leader approval.
- After graduating, use alumni benefits and stay connected via reunions, international networks, interest groups, and UCL Connect.

Caveats: Modules have caps; optional/elective places are not guaranteed; do not select modules you have already taken; exact change deadlines appear in the Module Selection Task on Portico.

Source: Module availability; Module selection; Approval of selections; Change of selections; UCL Alumni community
retrieved_contexts:
Module availability  
Modules for Computer Science students  
The programme diets for students on Computer Science programmes are set out on the Computer Science Student Intranet programme level pages. Students should pay attention to the specific rules and requirements for their programme, the modules available to them, and the volume of credit they must or may optionally take from any optional and elective groups.  
Modules for Ancillary students (non-Computer Science students)  
Ancillary students (i.e. those on a UCL programme at a department other than Computer Science) who wish to select Computer Science modules as optional, or elective, should refer to their own departments' programme pages for information on which modules are available to them. Ancillary students may only select Computer Science modules that are formally part of their programme's diet. If a module is compulsory for an Ancillary student, then they will be guaranteed a place, otherwise places will be allocated subject to remaining availability, the order of priority, the satisfaction of any requisite conditions, and final approval of the Module Leader and Programme Director.  
Modules for Affiliate students (Study Abroad, Erasmus, Exchange)  
Affiliate students (e.g. those on a Study Abroad, Erasmus, or Exchange programme) will be advised of the process for selecting modules by their home department. Modules may need to be selected before enrolment, or after arrival at UCL. Not all modules will be available to Affiliate students, particularly if a module's assessments would take place outside of the student's period of registration. Students should check with the relevant department to ensure they understand any restrictions and conditions.  
Computer Science | Study Abroad at UCL

Each module/ module delivery has a fixed upper limit on the number of places available (known as the 'module cap'), based on the department's teaching capacity and other resource constraints.  
Students are guaranteed a place on any modules that are compulsory on their programme/ year of study. However, places cannot be guaranteed on modules that are optional and elective, as availability will depend on how many places are left once any compulsory places have been assigned (i.e. a module that is optional on their programme may be compulsory on another.) Therefore, places will usually be allocated in the following order of priority: - Students for whom the module is compulsory (guaranteed a place.) - Students for whom the module is optional. - Students for whom the module is elective.  
Within those tiers, places will by default be allocated first to Computer Science students and then to non-Computer Science students on a first-come-first-serve basis within each group. If a student selects an optional or elective module that has no capacity remaining, is not formally available to them, or for which they do not satisfy any prerequisites, then their selection will be rejected, and they will be asked to select an alternative module.  
All module selections are ultimately subject to approval by the Module Leader and Programme Director.  
Overlapping content & re-registering on the same module  
Students must not select as optional or elective any module they have already taken, either in their current programme or during any prior studies. For example, if a module is available as an option in multiple terms or years of a programme, it can only be taken and passed once.

Computer Science | Study Abroad at UCL  
Module registration for affiliates | UCL Students  
Module selection  
Choosing modules for 2024-25  
Students needing to select optional or elective modules, will be able to do so from before the start of the academic year. New students can register for modules once they have completed pre-enrolment. Continuing students can register for modules once they have completed re-enrolment.  
Students must complete module registration by no later than 11 October 2024, however they are strongly encouraged to complete the process as early as possible.  
Module selection | UCL Students  
Approval of selections  
Students can check the approval status of their module selections in the 'My Modules' area on Portico. Decisions will be notified by email when selections are either approved or declined. Where a selection is rejected, students will be informed of the reason for this and asked to select an appropriate alternative module from the programme diet, subject to the usual requisite conditions and approval process.  
Change of selections  
Students wishing to change a module selection, must make a request to their home department in the first instance. Any change will be subject to the same requisites, orders of priority, and restrictions as an initial selection and must be approved by the Programme Director and the Module Leader.  
Exact deadlines for making changes to module selections will be published each year in the 'Module Selection Task' on Portico.  
Verification of selections
