Information on the UCL Students' Union Advice Service.  
The Students' Union Advice Service is available to all current UCL students, as well as those who have interrupted their studies or recently completed their programme. Trained and experienced staff are ready to support students with any difficulties that might occur during your time at UCL. The Advice Service specialises in: - Academic Advice - including extenuating circumstances, academic misconduct and the support to study framework - UCL Complaints and Disciplinaries - Housing Issues - including tenancy contract checks and housemate disputes - Employment Rights - including unpaid wages and part time employment contracts - Financial Support and Budgeting including income maximisation, money management and hardship funds
reference: The Students' Union Advice Service and the informal resolution routes at UCL work together to support students in addressing complaints effectively. The Advice Service offers free, independent, impartial, and confidential support to all current UCL students, including those who have interrupted their studies or recently completed their programme. It specialises in academic advice, complaints and disciplinaries, housing issues, employment rights, and financial support. Meanwhile, informal resolution encourages students to raise concerns directly with Personal Tutors, Programme Leaders, Departmental or Faculty Tutors, Course Representatives, or Research Student Representatives before submitting a formal complaint. Staff office hours, held regularly by Programme Directors and Module Leaders, provide informal drop-in sessions where students can raise issues, concerns, or problems without prior appointment. These sessions serve as an accessible first step for students to discuss their difficulties, potentially resolving matters locally. If issues remain unresolved, the Academic Representatives summarize concerns and escalate them within an Academic forum. Together, these mechanisms ensure students have multiple avenues for support and resolution, with the Advice Service complementing the informal routes by offering expert guidance and advocacy throughout the complaint process.

user_input: How do the Students' Union UCL and Course Representatives collaborate to ensure student representation and improve the student experience across UCL?
response:
The Students’ Union UCL trains and supports Course Representatives, who channel student feedback through Lead Department and Faculty Representatives into SPC/SSCC and teaching committees to drive improvements across UCL.

- In early October, stand for election as a Course Rep or vote for your reps via the Students’ Union.
- Share issues and ideas with your Course Rep; they work with staff and Lead Department Representatives in SSCCs (the main forum for student feedback).
- Lead Department Representatives liaise between Course Reps and the Students’ Union, co-chair SPC/SSCCs, and raise matters to the Departmental Teaching Committee.
- Faculty Representatives work closely with the Students’ Union to spot trends and escalate them to the Faculty Teaching Committee.

Note: Elections happen early October; SPCs meet at least three times a year and may be split into UG and PG.

Source: CS Student Partnership Committees & Academic Representatives | CS Student Intranet; Student representation and voice; Chapter 9, Section 6.4: Staff Student Consultative Committees | UCL Academic Manual

user_input: How does the UCL feedback policy ensure timely feedback during the assessment and examination periods, and what procedures are in place if feedback deadlines are not met?
response:
UCL ensures timely feedback by requiring it within one calendar month (CS aims 20 working days) and mandating advance notice of any delay (normally ≤1 week), with clear escalation if deadlines slip.

- Expect feedback within one calendar month of the deadline (CS target: 20 working days); project drafts get feedback in 10 working days if submitted ≥15 working days before the final deadline.
- Check your module’s Moodle forum for any advance delay notices from the department.
- If a delay occurs beyond the stated timescales, raise it with the module’s responsible Programme Director.
- If no delay notice appears on Moodle or issues persist, notify the Departmental Tutor directly or via your Course Representative.

Caveats: Feedback may be withheld until approved extensions conclude; exam scripts are not returned and exam feedback is usually cohort-level; provisional marks are not released for exams (coursework may receive provisional marks with feedback).

Source: UCL feedback policy; Computer Science feedback policy; Computer Science exam script policy; Computer Science provisional marks policy
retrieved_contexts:
UCL feedback policy  
It is UCL policy that all students receive feedback on summative assessments within one calendar month of the submission deadline. This feedback may take the form of indicative or provisional marks, written feedback, individual discussions, group discussions, marker’s answers, model answers or other solutions, although students should note that UCL is generally unable to return examination scripts.  
If, for whatever reason, a department/ division cannot ensure that the one calendar month deadline is met then they will tell students when the feedback will be provided, it is expected that the extra time needed should not exceed one week. Where feedback is not provided within the timescale, students should bring the matter to the attention of the module's responsible Programme Director.  
Computer Science feedback policy  
For taught modules, the department aims to release feedback for summative assessments within 20 working days of the date of the assessment/ submission deadline (i.e., excluding weekends, closure periods, and UK Bank Holidays). Feedback for some assessments may be withheld until any approved extensions have completed, i.e., to ensure no unfair advantage to students submitting later.  
For research project/ dissertation modules, the department aims to provide feedback on a draft version within 10 working days, provided the draft is received at least 15 working days prior to the final submission deadline.

The department will proactively monitor the return of feedback for Computer Science modules, and will take appropriate action where delays occur. Students should expect that any delay will be notified in advance via the module's Moodle forum. If this does not occur, students should notify the Departmental Tutor either directly or via their Course Representative.  
Computer Science exam script policy  
UCL is generally unable to return written examination scripts and will not do so as a means of providing feedback. Feedback on examinations should usually take the form of cohort-level feedback, which summarises general issues and areas for improvement based on the performance of the cohort. Individualised or highly detailed feedback is neither appropriate or possible for examinations.  
Computer Science provisional marks policy  
UCL permits departments to release provisional marks for assessments prior to their confirmation by the Board of Examiners. For coursework, provisional marks will usually be released alongside feedback on the assessment; sometimes feedback will be released first, and provisional marks will follow. For examinations, provisional marks will not be released, since the exams take place very close to the point confirmed results are published. In all cases, final marks will be released via Student Registry Services, following their confirmation by the Board of Examiners.

reference: UCL policy mandates that all students receive feedback on summative assessments within one calendar month of the submission deadline. For Computer Science taught modules, feedback is aimed to be released within 20 working days of the assessment deadline, excluding weekends, closure periods, and UK Bank Holidays. Feedback for some assessments may be withheld until approved extensions are completed to ensure fairness. If a department cannot meet the one calendar month deadline, they must inform students of the revised feedback date, which should not exceed an additional week. Should feedback not be provided within the expected timescale, students are advised to notify the module's responsible Programme Director. user_input: According to the UCL feedback policy and the assessment and examination periods for Computer Science modules, what are the expected timelines and forms of feedback students should anticipate for summative assessments and examinations during the academic year 2024/25?
response:
You should normally get coursework feedback within one calendar month (CS aims 20 working days), and exam feedback as cohort-level summaries (no scripts returned, no provisional exam marks). 
- Coursework: expect feedback within 1 calendar month of the deadline; CS aims for 20 working days (excl. weekends/closures/bank holidays); provisional coursework marks usually released with/after feedback; feedback may be held until approved extensions finish. 
- Examinations: main period 29 Apr–30 May 2025; late-summer 18 Aug–5 Sep 2025; feedback is cohort-level only, scripts are not returned, and provisional exam marks are not released; final marks come via Student Registry Services after Board confirmation. 
- Projects/dissertations: draft feedback within 10 working days if the draft is submitted ≥15 working days before the final deadline. 
- If feedback is late: the department should notify a new date (normally ≤1 extra week) via Moodle; if not, raise it with the module’s responsible Programme Director and notify the Departmental Tutor directly or via your Course Representative. 
- Timing context: most CS coursework is set within T1 Weeks 06–20 and T2 Weeks 21–32; deadlines are not set during closure periods, weekends, or UK bank holidays. 
Source: UCL feedback policy; Computer Science feedback, exam script, and provisional marks policies; Section 5: Assessment Feedback and Chapter 4, Section 3: Module Assessment (UCL Academic Manual)

user_input: What support and reporting procedures are in place at UCL for Student Visa students regarding their attendance, and how can these students contact the Student Enquiries Centre for assistance?
response:
UCL monitors Student Visa students’ engagement via RegisterUCL and the Student Immigration Compliance team and offers support if issues arise; I don't know based on the handbook excerpts provided how to contact the Student Enquiries Centre.

- Follow the CS Student Engagement Policy and UCL Student Attendance Policy, and always record attendance (scan your UCL ID in equipped rooms; access online sessions with UCL credentials).
- If you face attendance issues, contact your programme administration team as soon as possible for advice and support.
- If you cannot attend an assessment or meet a deadline due to circumstances, submit a Short-term Illness and Extenuating Circumstances application.
- Be aware: non-engagement may be reported to UKVI via RegisterUCL by your department or the Student Immigration Compliance team.

user_input: How does UCL incorporate student feedback to improve educational experiences, and what Student Support and Wellbeing services are available to assist students, including international students, with their visa and study-related enquiries?
response:
UCL gathers student feedback via student representation, staff office hours, and termly Module Evaluative Questionnaires (MEQs), and supports students through Student Support and Wellbeing and the Student Enquiries Centre, plus International Student Support and SPCS.

- Share feedback at Programme Director/Module Leader office hours (drop-in; see timetable/announcements; email if no slot).
- Complete MEQs at the end of each term to evaluate your modules.
- Visit the Student Enquiries Centre (1st floor, Student Centre) for walk-in guidance on visas, fees, study abroad, student records, and SSW queries.
- Register online with Student Psychological and Counselling Services (SPCS) for short-term CBT/psychodynamic support.
- If you’re a non-UK student, contact International Student Support for practical guidance (healthcare, banking, transport, safety) and ISOP.

Note: You are responsible for proactively seeking support; office hours may not run every week—your Personal Tutor/Programme Director/Administrator can help signpost services.

Source: Support services; Staff office hours; Surveys and questionnaires; Student Enquiries Centre; International Student Support; Student Psychological and Counselling Services; Chapter 9, Section 7 (Student Representation)

[Office Hours & Drop-in Sessions | CS Student Handbook](  
Surveys and questionnaires  
Students will be invited to provide feedback on their individual modules via Module Evaluative Questionnaires (MEQs) at the end of each term. These questionnaires ask about a students' learning experience, the resources and materials they have been provided with, the teaching they have received, and their views on what could be improved. More information on student feedback surveys is given in [Section 18 Student feedback and You Shape UCL | CS Student Handbook](

Support for disabled students | UCL Students  
Support for wellbeing and mental health | UCL Students  
Student Psychological and Counselling Services  
Student Psychological and Counselling Services (SPCS) is dedicated to helping UCL students with personal, emotional and psychological concerns. The SPCS team is diverse and consists of a variety of highly trained and experienced professionals, who offer short-term CBT and psychodynamic support. There are currently two psychiatrists and ten therapists on staff with varying kinds of psychological training and expertise.  
Students wishing to access counselling through SPCS need to first complete an online registration form via the SPCS website.  
International Student Support  
The International Student Support Team provide specialist support and advice for all non-UK students at UCL. They help international students settle into life in the UK and make the most of their time at UCL and in London. This includes practical guidance on healthcare, banking, transport and safety, as well as information about the International Student Orientation Programme (ISOP).  
International Students | UCL Students  
Study Abroad Support  
The Study Abroad team provide administrative and welfare support to all undergraduate students undertaking a period abroad as part of their studies, working with colleagues, including Study Abroad Tutors, across academic departments in order to advise and guide students from application through to their return to studies at UCL. The team coordinates a diverse portfolio of global student opportunities via different projects: Student Exchanges and Exchange Agreements, the Turing Scheme, Global Experience (Summer Schools, volunteering abroad, short-term mobility).

reference: UCL places great importance on student feedback by involving students as partners in shaping education. Feedback mechanisms include the student representative scheme, module dialogue via Moodle forums, departmental student voice platforms, and various student surveys such as the National Student Survey, Postgraduate Taught Experience Survey, and New to UCL survey. This feedback has led to tangible improvements like opening the Library during Christmas closure, increasing study spaces including 1000 seats in the 24-hour Student Centre, focusing on environmental sustainability, and providing clearer exam and assessment information. Regarding Student Support and Wellbeing, UCL offers a wide range of services to ensure a fulfilling and healthy student experience. Students are encouraged to proactively seek support through their Personal Tutor, Programme Director, or Programme Administrator. The Student Enquiries Centre (SEC), located on the 1st floor of the Student Centre, provides walk-in, telephone, and online askUCL enquiry services to assist with questions about student records, visas, fees, study abroad, and wellbeing. The SEC operates during term-time with specific hours for walk-in and telephone services, and self-service options are available via Portico and askUCL for efficient access to documentation and FAQs.
